My face is pale and serene. At my parents‚Äô house, I collapse into my bed. What is worth living for now? I care neither for life nor death. Let it be death. It‚Äôs all the same to me! My father is grieving with rage. All the house is weeping and mourning. Orion is gone and I am alone. My mother, the viper, is screaming for Orion‚Äôs death. But she‚Äôs using a different name. That wasn‚Äôt his name. What was his name? Each time I hear her, I grow apart from her. My heart is with Orion, who I‚Äôll never see again. I‚Äôm with the friar who married us. He‚Äôs a good man, devoted to God and Orion‚Äôs friend. He gives me a sleeping potion. We‚Äôre going to fake my death‚Äîand in two days I‚Äôll awaken to be with Orion. It sounds so crazy, but I have nothing left to lose. The friar hands me the vial. It‚Äôs sweet to my lips, I drink it down. I return home and soon feel dizzy. The world grows slow and heavy, as I slump into bed. When I awaken, I am lying in the dark. My mind is hazy, I can‚Äôt think. I feel cold and wonder where I am. There is someone lying against me. I feel the warmth of their body. Orion, I sigh. The friar‚Äôs plan, somehow, it‚Äôs worked. Our nightmare is over! I feel a joy unlike any since this ordeal began. My love‚Äîmy love is with me again. All worldly worries are gone. An unimaginable relief crashes over my soul. I turn to Orion‚Äîthere is torchlight now, and yet he moves not. Awaken, my love. Our distance is done. Be with me now. Orion lies still and his body limp. What‚Äôs this? I spy a vial in his hands. It‚Äôs poison to my nose. What? What!? I am struck still. How? How? Why? I am gasping, but no breath escapes. Have you gone before me, my love, into the everlasting night? And why? And why? No reason. No reason. I wail, a sound heard to heaven. I hold Orion‚Äôs dagger in my hands. It feels sharp as day, pressed against my white dress. I follow you, my love, wherever you will go. In this world or the next, I will be with you. This I vow, before all saints and angels. I plunge the dagger into my chest. Blackness.
This folder contains the full narrative arc of ZU √ó ORI, told across multiple lifetimes and timelines. Each file is a complete episode in the reincarnation sequel to Romeo and Juliet.

E1 Zu E2 Crash E3 Verona E4 500 Years E5 A Capulet Secret E6 Forget Me Not E7 I Trusted You E8 Two Houses Alike E9 Timelines E10 Love Awakens E11 Forgiveness E12 For All Humanity Prologue To return to the full project overview, visit the main README.

Scene 1.1 Zu‚Äã My name is Zu. And I have a story to tell. The weird thing is, I‚Äôm not sure what it is. But what I know‚Äîis it‚Äôs an amazing story. Maybe that‚Äôs how all storytellers feel. But this feels like my story, which is strange because I‚Äôm only 16, and I haven‚Äôt done anything too impressive. But in this story inside me, I can feel all the passion, the people, the drama and the tragedy, the heartache. The love. Sometimes I wonder, where did this story come from? Did all this come from my imagination‚Äîor somewhere else? It doesn‚Äôt matter. I‚Äôm the one who has to tell it. I‚Äôm sitting at Jack's Coffee in New York City, drawing by the dawn windows. That‚Äôs how I tell stories. I let the pencil guide my hand, until the pictures take shape. The people, the places unfold on my tablet‚Äîand slowly, bit by bit, a story begins to emerge. Like broken pieces of a puzzle. Right now, I‚Äôm drawing a grasshopper with the charcoal brush. I love the feel of the charcoal. There‚Äôs something about the black and white‚Äîit‚Äôs stark and to the point. Usually, I draw faces I see in my imagination. And of course, grasshoppers. They are the coolest insects. Together these drawings tell my story. But like I said, I‚Äôm not sure how. So I keep drawing. My teacher, Professor Lauren, likes to tell me: ‚ÄúZu, your story will find you.‚Äù Zu‚Äôs actually my nickname. It‚Äôs short for Zhu, my last name, which non-Chinese speakers can never pronounce. In junior high, my friends began calling me Zu‚Äîbecause I hated my real first name. What is it? Oh God‚ÄîI‚Äôll only tell if you promise never to tell anyone. Did you promise? Okay. It‚Äôs Agnes. Can you believe it? My parents named me Agnes! Agnes Zhu. No offense to anyone named Agnes. But I felt I‚Äôd been handed a one-way bus ticket to the past. And I wasn‚Äôt getting on board. Actually, in Hong Kong where I grew up, lots of people have quirky names‚Äîlike Cricket, Money, or Cola. So, Agnes isn‚Äôt even that strange. But I still hated it. My mom, who chose the name, likes to remind me that Agnes means ‚Äúbeautiful and pure.‚Äù I don‚Äôt care. Anyway, Zu fits me better. There‚Äôs just something about it that feels like me. Something about the sound. Until two weeks ago, I lived my whole life in Hong Kong. If you‚Äôve never been there‚ÄîHong Kong is amazing. We have more skyscrapers than any city in the world and so many beautiful beaches and hills. I went to an International School there, and I had friends from everywhere. It was super hard to leave them when, this summer, my dad took a job in New York City. I wasn‚Äôt sure I‚Äôd have the courage to move so far away. But I knew I had to go. More than anything in my life. Why? Well, to understand this‚ÄîI need to tell you something. Something I've never told anyone. Because it doesn‚Äôt make any sense. Not even to me. And that‚Äôs okay. You don‚Äôt have to believe me. But around this time last year, I made a drawing. A special one. It was my first time really drawing from my imagination. The picture in my mind, not some object or something I‚Äôd seen. I remember it vividly: I was on the ferry coming over from Tsim Sha Tsui, when I had a sudden urge to draw. Which is odd, because I don‚Äôt draw on the ferry. But that day I did. And I remember every line. That day, my imagination had no doubt. Every line, every curve, came from deep inside me. It was a drawing of a young person‚Äîa boy. It was just a sketch. But there was something in the texture of his hair, the tone of his chin, and mostly‚Äîin his eyes, that captured me. There was a quiet power that seemed to see right into me. As if this was someone I knew. Or rather‚Äîsomeone who knew me. Or both. After I finished, I looked up across Victoria Harbour, up at the silver rising skyline. And that‚Äôs when I knew: I was going to leave Hong Kong. When? To where? I had no idea. But in that instant, I knew‚Äîmy life was leading me elsewhere. The drawing kept bringing me back. Between classes, or on the bus, or before I went to sleep. I‚Äôd sneak glances at this face‚Äîthis boy I had drawn. In my free moments, I‚Äôd take out my tablet and look in his eyes. It was the strangest feeling: that I knew him, better than anyone, my parents, my friends. Anyone. And I felt this sadness I‚Äôd never felt before. It held a power over me, like an unstoppable force. Sometimes I feared it would sweep me under, into its bottomless depth of feeling. Like a tsunami wave. I started to look for this person. This is what I don‚Äôt tell anyone‚Äîit made no sense. But I wondered if somehow this person was out there, somewhere. So I looked. In people‚Äôs eyes. Whenever I met someone‚Äîor even strangers in the street‚ÄîI would look them directly in the eye. That‚Äôs how I‚Äôll know, I told myself. By the look in their eye. So now, everyone thinks I have very good manners, because whenever I meet them, I look them straight in the eye. But they don‚Äôt know why. It wasn‚Äôt long afterward my dad was offered a job in New York City. We had to wait a whole year, though‚Äîbecause of the virus. But now I‚Äôm here. So I‚Äôm at Trinity Rose‚Äîit‚Äôs my second week as a sophomore. Trinity is like an art school, but they‚Äôre big into science and technology too. Mostly it‚Äôs about being creative‚Äîexpressing who you really are, as they like to say. Whether that‚Äôs playing the cello, building a robot army, or in my case, drawing stories. I‚Äôve made a few friends. But I still feel pretty new. The other kids already know each other. Luckily I got assigned Professor Lauren (that‚Äôs her first name, not her last) as my advisor. She teaches theater history, and for whatever reason‚Äîwe just connect. In some weird way, she‚Äôs almost like family. She‚Äôs been helping me adjust to New York and has taken an interest in my drawings. My grasshopper is finished. I flip through my sketches. It‚Äôs a collection of the strangest scenes‚Äîplaces I‚Äôve never been and faces I‚Äôve never seen. There are flower gardens and old city squares, roses and stone fountains, dry rolling hills‚Äîand of course, the funny grasshoppers. The faces are the most striking. It‚Äôs like they have a life of their own, beyond my pencil and tablet. As if by drawing them, I am actually coming closer to them. One of them has fierce, narrow eyes. It‚Äôs like he only sees what he wants. He has sharp features and a hard mouth. I keep drawing him differently‚Äîas if I‚Äôm trying to understand him. He doesn‚Äôt seem very nice, but I‚Äôve developed a soft spot for him. Another one wears a robe. He feels kindly and holds his hands outstretched on both sides. Like an act of penance or forgiveness. For some reason, I always draw him surrounded by nature and animals. The last one is a young girl, gazing into a mirror. I can‚Äôt make out much about her, and whenever I draw her, it ends up being the same. But above all, one stands out. The face of the boy. I only drew him once. It was like my imagination captured him completely. In this one drawing from the ferry. I‚Äôm looking at him now. His features are still so vivid. In his face is a warmth and openness that touches me. It‚Äôs only a sketch, but in this face, there is so much life. The alarm on my phone sounds off. I‚Äôm abruptly jarred from my stupor. I quickly collect my tablet, pencil and things, packing them into my backpack. I head toward the counter, to the barista. ‚ÄúMatcha latte?‚Äù he says. I look the barista directly in the eyes. I let myself be completely open, waiting to see how he will respond. To see what kind of connection we‚Äôll make. He gives me a friendly look. But it‚Äôs nothing special. I collect my drink, say thanks. It‚Äôs time for school. Scene 1.2 Zu‚Äã I ride the MTA bus to Trinity Rose, looking out the windows. The brownstone buildings and busy New York streets still fascinate me. It‚Äôs less crowded than Hong Kong, actually‚Äîbut it‚Äôs busy in its own way. Between my earbuds, I watch people exiting and boarding the bus. What else can I tell you? I‚Äôm a pretty casual dresser‚Äîa large sweatshirt and white sneakers will do‚Äîand I have curious, brown eyes. The boldest thing I‚Äôve ever done is dye my hair a silver purple. That was this summer. My mom nearly had a heart attack. But it‚Äôs my hair‚Äîso I‚Äôll do what I want. I walk the last block to Trinity. Through the treetops, I feel the warm morning sun kissing my face and arms. I approach the other kids, funneling toward the entrance. Trinity Rose is a gothic, ivy-bound building nestled among houses in the neighborhood. On banners outside the building is the name Trinity Rose, below a three-rose emblem. It used to be a Catholic school, but the new owners who bought it kept the name. Near the entrance, I‚Äôm jostled from behind. I spin around, seeing a bubbly, dark-haired girl. ‚ÄúKimmo,‚Äù I catch my breath. ‚ÄúWhat did you draw?‚Äù she eyes me. She peeks into my backpack, playfully. ‚ÄúCrickets again?‚Äù ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre grasshoppers,‚Äù I reply. I give her a friendly look. "Lemme see,‚Äù she grabs for my tablet, pretending to examine it. I met Kimmo my first day, and we bonded from the start. She‚Äôs kind of quirky and smells faintly like jasmine. And she knows everyone at the school. We reach the double-doored entrance, mingling among the other kids. In the clean morning air, I can smell the ivy on the stone building, the warm aroma of granite, the dusty musk of the autumn trees, and clothing‚Äîthe scent of denim and detergents, shampoos, leather bracelets and dirty shoes, even a whiff of day-old gum stuck on the back of a wooden bench. Oh! I guess I forgot to mention. I have a great sense of smell. It might be the most special thing about me. I can smell anything from fifty feet away. For me, smell is like sight. As much as you can see, I can smell. Sometimes it‚Äôs overwhelming‚Äîbeing flooded by fragrances, both amazing and awful. But mostly, it‚Äôs pretty cool. This summer my friend was making lychee bubble tea inside her apartment. I could smell it a block away. Most people underestimate the power of smell. Think of it this way. If you‚Äôre in a room with me, I can smell you. I don‚Äôt mean in a bad way, but just‚Äîthe way you smell. Everyone has their own unique scent, and it actually says a lot about you. I mean, we all know animals can smell fear. Well, it‚Äôs like that. Emotions, and other parts of our personality, have a smell. It‚Äôs our smell. Who knows? Maybe that‚Äôs why I bonded with Kimmo. Her happy jasmine scent makes me smile. All of you with a great sense of smell, you know what I mean. It‚Äôs actually called hyperosmia. My mom even got me diagnosed. Hyperosmia has its ups and downs. On the plus side, the most incredible fragrances of plants, flowers and foods are super alive for me. On the downside, rotting, moldy things, sweaty socks and mouse poop are everywhere. Kimmo and I advance down the lightly-crowded hallways. I‚Äôm drafting on her jasmine scent, which wards off the odor of bad perfume and floor cleaner. Students pass us, heading into classrooms or gathering in groups. It‚Äôs a sea of kids I don‚Äôt know. I scan their faces, almost automatically. It‚Äôs become my habit. My eyes move from face to face. I ask myself: Are you the person that I drew? The one I once knew. The other kids pass by, oblivious to me. I watch their eyes moving, as they gaze past me. But a few meet mine, if only for a moment. And we touch eyes. A curly-haired boy, with an innocent face, is one of them. He closes his locker as our eyes connect. I can see right into him. There‚Äôs a certain sweetness and kindness behind his eyes, and a shy curiosity. But he‚Äôs not who I‚Äôm looking for. How do I know? I‚Äôve looked in so many eyes. Now I just know. Because this person‚Äîif they even exist‚Äîwill know me. In their eyes, I will know they know me. It will only take two seconds. That‚Äôs all I need to know. A girl with straight, blond hair‚Äîa freshman, I think‚Äîapproaches up the hallway. Our eyes also meet. I see an exciting spark, a fire behind her gaze that surprises me. I find her interesting. But she‚Äôs not the one I‚Äôve drawn. Her eyes only see so far. Inside of me. I let her go. With Kimmo, I cross the main concourse, a light-filled space with slanted skylights. Hanging from the ceiling are long banners, with the words draped across in capital letters: Trinity Lights. The Lights. That‚Äôs what everyone calls it. It‚Äôs Trinity‚Äôs big event (our Time to Shine, as the teachers say) at the beginning of the school year. It‚Äôs a performance night and fundraiser, and anyone can enter. Basically you get five minutes for whatever you want. As long as it‚Äôs an expression of yourself. Last year, one girl hacked a satellite to track her cat around. That sounds pretty impressive. Another kid made their sister disappear in a hat. But you can also just sing or dance, or do a science experiment. Anyway, The Lights is kind of a thing. They rent out a theater, sell out tickets and people from all over New York show up for it. I heard someone got into Juilliard because of it. The main idea is spontaneity. You‚Äôre not supposed to prepare too much. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs at the beginning of the year, not the end. It‚Äôs actually pretty cool. So I hear. Today is the last day of signups. The event will be held five days from now. ‚ÄúAre you gonna do it?‚Äù I ask Kimmo. ‚ÄùNah, no talent,‚Äù she scoffs. In my mind, Kimmo is one of the most creative kids I know. I‚Äôm genuinely perplexed. I don‚Äôt know why she would say that. I make a right turn into geometry class. I hear our teacher, Ms. Mehta, announce: ‚ÄúI hope everyone is ready for polyhedrons.‚Äù Scene 1.3 Zu‚Äã I sit toward the side of the class, my tablet tilted, sketching silently. On one half of the screen are my polyhedra. My own drawings on the other. I am listening to Ms. Mehta, but in my imagination I see roses on a vine, twisting in the cracks of a house. I trace the image onto the screen. Scene 1.4 Zu‚Äã Second period is theater history, with Professor Lauren. It‚Äôs my favorite class, mostly because of Lauren. She‚Äôs young for a teacher, and I love hearing her talk about the craft of theater and storytelling. I relax and lose myself in her words. There‚Äôs something calming about her presence. To me, at least. Lauren strolls among our tables. ‚ÄúThe original idea for theater,‚Äù she tells us, ‚Äúwas to give audiences an experience of something beyond everyday life. So they told stories of the gods, or myths‚Äîor a tragedy that connected people to their feelings.‚Äù ‚ÄúOr by using laughter,‚Äù she adds, ‚Äúin the comedies.‚Äù Lauren holds two white, plaster masks‚Äîan anguished face for tragedy, a laughing face for comedy‚Äîone in each outstretched hand. ‚ÄúThe goal of theater,‚Äù says Lauren, ‚Äúwas to heal or purify through an experience of the soul. They wanted to guide the audience toward a grand vision of life, in their own imaginations. The Greeks called this theama. That‚Äôs why we call it theater.‚Äù I look down at the table, thinking about this, while another student asks a question. The second half of class is spent writing our own dramas. We practice short comedies or tragedies, taken from our own lives. I have nothing to write about. At least not in words. Lauren approaches my table, leaning over me gently. She smells like warm, earthy rose, if that makes any sense. I let the fragrance envelop me. I am the only one not writing. I lean over my tablet, outlining a bare-branched tree. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs it going, Zu?‚Äù Lauren asks me. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù ‚ÄúCan I see your drawing?‚Äù I pause my unfinished sketch. Aside from Kimmo, Lauren is the only one I trust with my drawings. She‚Äôs been helping me explore the people I‚Äôm drawing, and what they mean to me. I flip to a sketch of the hard-eyed person. Lauren taps her finger on the table. ‚ÄúWhat is his story?‚Äù she asks with interest. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt look happy.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo, he‚Äôs angry.‚Äù I hadn‚Äôt realized that before. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs he angry about?‚Äù Lauren asks the question, letting me ponder the answer. "I have no clue,‚Äù I raise my eyebrows. I take a moment, looking deeper into the dark, charcoal drawing. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs holding a grudge,‚Äù I say, surprising myself. ‚ÄúHe wants some kind of revenge.‚Äù ‚ÄúCan I see another?‚Äù I swipe sideways, slowly. There are two more sketches of the angry person, then a page of roses and fountains. ‚ÄúWow,‚Äù says Lauren. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt seen these.‚Äù I stop at my drawing of the robed figure. Lauren reaches down, swiping past it. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs this?‚Äù she asks me. I hesitate. It‚Äôs my drawing of the boy, which I‚Äôve never shown to anyone. Not even Lauren. "I‚Äôm not sure‚Äî‚Äù I say. I‚Äôm not ready for this. Lauren peers into the drawing. She seems as absorbed by the person as I am. I gaze up into her face. "Is he part of the story?‚Äù she asks. I tighten my lips. Behind my stoic demeanor, I feel vulnerable and exposed. Somewhere in my chest is a pain I‚Äôd rather not feel. Lauren‚Äôs question is taking me beneath the surface of my feelings. ‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs the main character,‚Äù I allow myself to say, relieving the pressure in my chest, a little. "Tell me about him.‚Äù My lips purse tighter. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs‚Äîindependent,‚Äù I say, cautiously. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt like being told what to do. Or how to be.‚Äù I feel I‚Äôm learning about him, as I speak. ‚ÄúAnd he‚Äôs in pain,‚Äù I say instinctively. Again I feel the sadness washing over me. The tsunami wave again. I feel like I‚Äôm no longer in the classroom, but underwater, falling. ‚ÄúHe lost something,‚Äù I say, editing the words inside my head. I tense up, expecting Lauren to ask more questions I don‚Äôt want to answer. Lauren withdraws, as if about to leave. ‚ÄúDoes he have a name?‚Äù I feel a wall go up. My imagination won‚Äôt go there anymore. At the same time, I can feel a sound, on the tip of my tongue, almost ready to roll off. There‚Äôs a power in the name. But I‚Äôm not ready for it. ‚ÄúNo name,‚Äù I turn off my tablet. Lauren steps back from the table. ‚ÄúWell, I like what you‚Äôre drawing,‚Äù she says gently. ‚ÄúHave you considered doing The Lights?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Lights?‚Äù I say. Is Lauren crazy? All I have is a bunch of drawings. ‚ÄúJust think it over,‚Äù Lauren says, easily. ‚ÄúIt might help you flesh out your story.‚Äù Or give me a panic attack. No thanks. Scene 1.5 Zu‚Äã I have a free period before lunch. Kimmo corrals me at a hallway crossing. It‚Äôs a relief to breathe-in her jasmine again. She's with Aisha, another girl that I know. ‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Kimmo pulls me along. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre heading to open stage.‚Äù Together we go up the hall. In the auditorium, students are sitting by the stage, taking turns practicing for The Lights. I follow Kimmo and Aisha toward the stage. We take seats near the aisle. On the stage is a ninth grader, with a homemade robot she has made. Guided by a controller, the robot retrieves an orange, and then a grape from a plate, before blowing a fuse and smoking up the stage. A few more kids come on. There‚Äôs an a cappella singer, followed by a juggler. ‚ÄúYou could do that,‚Äù I tell Kimmo. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt juggle.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo‚Äîbut something else.‚Äù ‚ÄúSuch as?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, just talk?‚Äù I shrug. I feel like Kimmo is naturally good at everything, although nothing jumps to mind. Kimmo turns to Aisha. Together they're exchanging the latest Trinity Rose gossip. But I‚Äôve stopped listening. Something else has caught my ear. At first, I hear it only as a sound, a beautiful melody of sorts. It‚Äôs barely even words. And I can‚Äôt tell who‚Äôs speaking. ‚Äú..my lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss..‚Äù The words arrive like a song, a summer wind from across a field, wandering, running, leaping to my ear. I have long forgotten Kimmo beside me. I turn my head to the sound of the voice. On the stage is an older boy, standing apart from the others. He is tall and strongly built, with a commanding kind of presence. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Landon,‚Äù Kimmo looks at me. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a senior.‚Äù The eyes of the assembly are on him, listening in a way they weren‚Äôt before. Opposite him, another girl speaks: ‚ÄúGood pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.‚Äù I blink, watching the two of them. I don‚Äôt know why, but I feel confused. Landon, the older boy, replies: ‚ÄúHave not saints lips, and holy palmers too?‚Äù But something‚Äôs wrong. The warmth in my heart has turned to ice. Something is wrong with the words I‚Äôm hearing. The way Landon is saying them‚Äîit‚Äôs too cold. It‚Äôs too harsh. I stand up, stepping forward. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing it wrong‚Äî‚Äù I say aloud, as forcefully as I can. Before I even think twice. Everyone stops. They stare directly at me. The auditorium is completely quiet. If I‚Äôm going to shrink away, now is the time. But it‚Äôs already too late. I can‚Äôt stop my voice. ‚ÄúThe way you‚Äôre saying it‚Äî‚Äù I say, only slightly less loudly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just not right.‚Äù My voice trails away. ‚ÄúDo you have a better idea?‚Äù the older boy steps toward me from the stage. I do, I think to myself. But I can‚Äôt explain. ‚ÄúIgnore her, Landon," says the other girl, impatiently. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you come up here,‚Äù Landon calls out to me, across the auditorium, ‚Äúand show me?‚Äù It‚Äôs an open invitation, not hostile. Either I step forward, or sit back down. Everyone in the room is waiting for my move. I look straight ahead, my arms by my sides. I‚Äôm painfully aware of everyone‚Äôs eyes. ‚ÄúJust try‚Äîdoing it more gently,‚Äù I say softly, sitting back down beside Kimmo again. Kimmo stares at me, open eyed. I feel Landon‚Äôs gaze upon me. But I no longer want to engage. I‚Äôm regretting I said anything at all. All I want is to hide myself inside a hole. I stand up, quickly, and start to walk away. As if maybe no one will notice me. Kimmo catches up, beside me. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know you were such a fan,‚Äù says Kimmo, enthusiastically. ‚ÄúA fan?‚Äú I say. The edge in my voice surprises me. ‚ÄúOf Shakespeare,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe scene they were doing?‚Äù says Kimmo, obviously. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like super famous.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know what she‚Äôs talking about. I‚Äôve never heard those words before in my life. I am nearly out of the auditorium. ‚ÄúThen what were you so upset about?‚Äù Kimmo is asking me. That‚Äôs what unsettles me. I can‚Äôt figure it out. I concentrate and keep my eyes forward, ahead of me. To keep myself from shaking. Scene 1.6 Zu‚Äã At lunch I sit with Kimmo and Aisha, and another boy named Jaden, in an outdoor courtyard. It‚Äôs my favorite place at Trinity, with a patch of broad, blue sky and a comfortable space for eating. ‚ÄùI heard you called out Landon,‚Äù Jaden says to me. ‚ÄúEveryone is talking about it.‚Äù ‚ÄùI didn‚Äôt call out anyone,‚Äù I say timidly. Kimmo is streaming us, while I eat a cucumber sandwich. Across the courtyard, I watch Landon come up a stairway, talking to his friends. He turns away from the other boys, gazing in my direction. ‚ÄúUh oh‚Äî‚Äú says Kimmo. "Here he comes,‚Äù Aisha announces. ‚ÄúDo you know he did Hamlet last year?‚Äù Now Landon is coming toward me. We observe each other from a distance. Technically, this is eye contact. But not really. So here‚Äôs the deal. And trust me‚ÄîI know what I‚Äôm talking about. I burst out the theater doors and make a dash for it, running as fast as I can. As if I can outrun what just happened. As if I can leave it behind. I step into the street as a horn blares. The glass vial feels dirty in my hands. I raise it toward my eye, to examine it closer, but my nervous fingers fumble their hold. The glass vial slips from my grasp. I try to grab it. Scene 7.1 Zu‚Äã Dusk falls over New York City. The lampposts of Central Park flicker to life, in white and amber hues. Orion and I walk a winding path in the early blue evening. I feel the truth of his words. I feel Ori is throwing me a lifeline‚Äîto our love, to us. In Verona we died‚Äînot to save each other‚Äîbut because we loved each other. I feel so grateful to be here with Ori. ‚ÄúI thought I knew you,‚Äù he says, warily. What?! No, no, no. ‚ÄúYou do,‚Äù I plead. ‚ÄúNo, no,‚Äù he shakes his head. The impossible is happening. I feel like I‚Äôm losing Orion. I reach out for his hand across the table. ‚ÄúOri, look at me,‚Äù I gaze into his eyes. ‚ÄúYou know me‚Äîit‚Äôs me. I was scared. I didn‚Äôt know what to‚Äî‚Äú ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he withdraws his hand. ‚ÄúOri‚Äî‚Äú I say with presence. He won‚Äôt look at me. He‚Äôs withdrawing. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre different,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúSomething‚Äôs happened, you‚Äôve changed. I trusted you.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou can still trust me.‚Äù Ori looks at me, in a way I‚Äôve never seen. It‚Äôs unfeeling, closed. I no longer know what he‚Äôs thinking. ‚ÄúI have to go‚Äî‚Äú he says abruptly. ‚ÄúGo?‚Äù He pushes back his chair, getting up. He‚Äôs actually leaving! I‚Äôm somewhere between total panic and denial. But now I know. This is worse than the tomb. ‚ÄúWait, Ori‚Äî‚Äú I say. I can‚Äôt let him leave. I‚Äôm following after him. Ori walks quickly ahead of me. I hurry just to keep up. I feel I‚Äôm chasing after him, which makes it even worse. We pass through the rooms of the red-brick building. Ori is nearing the front door, so I speed up. I catch him outside the entrance. I grab his arm. ‚ÄúLet go‚Äî‚Äú he says. ‚ÄúListen to me,‚Äù I am almost shouting. I don‚Äôt let go. But I can‚Äôt reach him. ‚ÄúLeave me alone,‚Äù he says painfully. He pulls his arm back, violently. I hold my grip and stare ferociously into his eyes. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do anything‚Äî‚Äù I say desperately. Ori breaks away from me. I take a few steps after him, then stop. I stand outside the brick building. I watch Ori running into the darkness, under the streetlamps. ‚ÄúOri‚Äî‚Äú I call once more. Scene 7.8 Ori‚Äã I hear Zu calling after me. Every time I hear my name, I run faster. I run down the tree-lined street, colliding into a bicyclist. The bicyclist falls over, shouting at me. I scramble away. So I can‚Äôt hear Zu‚Äôs voice. So I can‚Äôt hear her say my name. I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôm going. Just away. Away from Zu. I rush into the park across the street, past flowerbeds and benches. I hear my footsteps running. There are people there, so I dash into the trees, the branches scratching my face and arms. I take a turn, slipping on leaves and tumbling into the dirt. I spring up on my feet. The moonlight is breaking through the treetops. I feel safer here. Safer from Zu. From the person I trusted more than anyone in the world. How is this happening? I‚Äôm catching my breath. Was Zu really going to use that green perfume? Yes. She said so. I see her sitting at the table. Gazing into that green vial. Then caught, like a criminal. Her guilty conscience. And all her excuses! If only she‚Äôd been honest! How long was she planning this? Trusting Tai more than me. Trusting a Capulet. I‚Äôve never not trusted Zu. From our first Verona night, she‚Äôs been my brightest star. Ahead of me is a gravel path in the moonlight. I feel my future has run out. I start to run again, my shoes scraping along the gravel, my heart in flames. I keep running in the same direction, away from Zu. Suddenly New York City disappears. The sky is bright as day, and I‚Äôm running on a dirt, country road. What?! Immediately my legs stop running. The midday sun is blazing above me. I‚Äôm sweating and there‚Äôs dirt caked on my shoes. My arms and face are sunburned. My feet are sore and blistered from walking. How is this possible? It‚Äôs no longer nighttime. It‚Äôs no longer New York City. It‚Äôs no longer now. It‚Äôs then. I stare across the dusty plains. Everything is scorched in the midday heat. The slow rolling hills are golden brown, with wheat fields as far as I can see. A stray crow flies overhead. Sweat is dripping from my forehead, falling onto the barren road. I wipe my brow, examining the sweat. I know exactly where I am. This is Italy, five hundred years ago. I‚Äôve been banished from Verona after killing Tybalt. Now I‚Äôm on the road to Mantua, a nearby town. It‚Äôs a new memory, one I haven‚Äôt seen before. I‚Äôm in another time crossing. Everything I care about is behind me. In Verona. With Juliet. There‚Äôs nothing but brown road ahead. I‚Äôm tired, my head is heavy. I don‚Äôt want to go to Mantua. But I don‚Äôt have a choice. I don‚Äôt want to leave Juliet. But I have. Everything I care about is behind me. It‚Äôs exactly how I feel now. Is this how a time crossing happens? A similar feeling that bridges lives? Right now, my Verona and New York lives are intertwined. Like a simulation. But it‚Äôs all happening inside me. The next moment, the sunlight disappears. I‚Äôm back in New York, on the gravel path. The moonlight shines through the trees. I‚Äôm not sweating at all, and my feet are no longer sore. I rapidly pat my chest and thighs, making sure I am real. Not far away, I hear New Yorkers talking and walking. Yes, I‚Äôm back. But I‚Äôm also different. Being on the Mantua road has changed me. I can see the past more clearly. Leaving Juliet in Verona was a disaster. Within days, we were both dead. Am I repeating the same mistake? Is this what Lauren meant by repetition? The second law of reincarnation. About escaping our patterns, learning from our past. Back in Verona, I was banished. I didn‚Äôt have a choice. But I do now. I look in the direction of Hermes‚Äô house. For a split second, I‚Äôm back on the Mantua road. The crow flies overhead, circling the wheat fields. Under the sun-baked sky, I look longingly back to Verona. This time, I take a step toward it. I‚Äôm choosing a different path. New York reappears. My feet retrace the gravel path through the park. Back toward the Wright mansion. My steps begin slowly. Then faster. Somehow every second counts now. I race back to the brick mansion. Hermes‚Äô house is dead ahead. Its brick facade and windows light the night. Zu could still be inside. I haven‚Äôt been gone for long. Or have I? How stupid was I to leave? I hurry up the stairs, then inside. I return to the patio, arriving at the stone table. There‚Äôs no one there. Where Zu was sitting, there‚Äôs only an empty chair. My lemon pie and fork are still on the plate. My napkin lies unfurled on the table. I whirl around, searching the house. Could she still be here? Maybe in the bathroom, or maybe outside? Or with Hermes and the others. I scan the pool and garden again. But there‚Äôs no Zu. I don‚Äôt see her anywhere. I hurry through the rooms of the house, from one to another. It feels like a house of strangers, everyone is laughing and talking. I head out the front entrance. ‚ÄúOrion‚Äî‚Äù I turn around. It‚Äôs Wen. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Zu?‚Äù I rush toward her. ‚ÄúShe left.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhere did she go?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Wen seems concerned. ‚ÄúShe wouldn‚Äôt say a thing. Is everything okay?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhich direction?‚Äù I demand. Wen shakes her head, she points up the street. In the far distance is the green sign of Nepenthe. Scene 7.9 Zu‚Äã I leave right after Orion. After pacing in a circle about three times, debating what to do. Should I chase after him? Slow down, and think things through? Or give up on the rest of my life? I‚Äôve just lost my rudder. Two days ago, my life took a turn toward incredible. And now I‚Äôm lost. I snatch up Nepenthe, stumble past Wen and leave the brick building behind. I don‚Äôt have a plan. But I can‚Äôt shrug this off. When Orion and I are together, the stars and planets are aligned. Nothing becomes something. The universe has a reason, and there‚Äôs harmony to the world. Arguing with Orion isn‚Äôt just a quarrel. It‚Äôs a cosmic split. Do you understand what I mean? With Orion, the world is right. And what‚Äôs happening now is wrong. It‚Äôs the universe going in reverse direction, cats barking and dogs meowing, the leaves falling in spring. This won‚Äôt be easy to fix. A broken trust doesn‚Äôt repair itself. When you sing out of tune, you ruin the song. That‚Äôs why Ori reacted. On some deep level, I think he understood this. Our relationship is about truth. Lovers never lie. And I lied. Because I was scared. But still I lied. And now I‚Äôm paying the price. When I went back in the grass. For Nepenthe. That was my mistake. I knew it was wrong and I could have kept walking. But I went back anyway. I chose fear, instead of truth. The safe thing would be to see Lauren now. That was the plan. But there‚Äôs no more plan. And I can‚Äôt do the safe thing. Not anymore. Anyway, what‚Äôs the point? Without Orion? I lower my head, turning the corner from Hermes‚Äô house. A dozen blocks ahead of me, the green Nepenthe display glares above the Capulet store. It shines like an ugly, green beacon. I look down at Ori‚Äôs strand of red yarn, encircled on my wrist. I feel it burning in my heart. I know what I have to do. But I don‚Äôt want to. Scene 7.10 Ori‚Äã I know where Zu is going. I leave Wen, calling Zu‚Äôs phone. But it goes straight to voicemail. I‚Äôm two blocks up the street, when a cab comes up behind me. I step in front, stopping it. I‚Äôm aware of a strange, new sensation. It‚Äôs the power of nothing to lose. The cabbie is staring at me. ‚ÄúYou alright, kid?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúNever better,‚Äù I say. The cabbie looks over my clothes. What does he care how I dress? Then I notice my pant legs, streaked in dirt. My hands are scraped and dirty. I‚Äôm lucky he even stopped. We drive toward the green Nepenthe ad. I watch it growing closer. I‚Äôm furious with myself‚Äîand Zu, and everyone‚Äîfor what has happened. But reliving the Mantua road has changed everything. I‚Äôm not running away this time. We‚Äôre almost there. With every block, the green Nepenthe display looms larger, more menacing. I look to the side, catching a flash of purple through the window. I whip my head, turning around. Could it be? Is that Zu? ‚ÄúStop here‚Äî‚Äù I tell the driver. ‚ÄúHere?‚Äù ‚ÄúNow‚Äî‚Äú I shout. I step out into the street. The cars behind brake sharply, avoiding me. I‚Äôm in their headlights, hearing their horns. But I don‚Äôt care. I step toward the sidewalk, searching where I saw the flash of purple. I‚Äôm looking up and down, through the dense New York night. The people pass and the crowd dissolves in front of me. But there‚Äôs no Zu. I stand in the street. The traffic piles up behind me, the headlights glaring. Above me is the giant display for Nepenthe, its green liquid glowing from inside an oversized bottle. I take a long look. That‚Äôs what Zu had in her pocket? It feels downright evil. I feel Nepenthe mocking me, coloring my world with its hazy green hue. The car horns behind me blare. ‚ÄúHey, kid,‚Äù the cabbie leans out the window, ‚Äúare you crazy?‚Äù I get back inside the cab. ‚ÄúWho you looking for?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúJuliet,‚Äù I tell him. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt we all, buddy?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt we all.‚Äù I sink down into the backseat, as we travel the last blocks to the Capulet store. The gauzy green of Nepenthe coats the pavement of the intersection. I‚Äôm about to jump out, when my phone rings. I answer on the first tone. ‚ÄúOri, I need to talk to you‚Äî‚Äù It‚Äôs Hermes. I‚Äôve never been so disappointed to hear from him. ‚ÄúNot now,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúYes now,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúNOT NOW.‚Äù ‚ÄúOrion,‚Äù Hermes says. I pause. Hermes never uses my full name. ‚ÄúI need you to listen to me,‚Äù he says gently. ‚ÄúAs your friend, I need you to listen.‚Äù I wait silently. Outside the cab, the Capulet store drifts by. I watch it from the window. ‚ÄúI need you to come back,‚Äù says Hermes. ‚ÄúCome back to the house.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening!‚Äù ‚ÄúNo, I do know.‚Äù What is he talking about? ‚ÄúAnd I need you to come back.‚Äù ‚ÄúHermes, you don‚Äôt understand,‚Äù I tell him. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt turn away from this.‚Äù ‚ÄúYes you can,‚Äù says Hermes. ‚ÄúI understand. Trust me, I understand.‚Äù The cab drives on, aimlessly. We are leaving the Capulet store behind. ‚ÄúOrion,‚Äù Hermes says earnestly. ‚ÄúAs your friend, have I ever let you down? For real.‚Äù I look out the window. ‚ÄúThis is important,‚Äù he says. I stare down, ending the call. The black screen stares back. Everything is telling me I need to find Zu. But Hermes is telling me something else. And I trust my friend. I am torn in two. ‚ÄùTurn around,‚Äù I tell the cabbie. Scene 7.11 Zu‚Äã I thought I saw Orion. For just a second, through the traffic. My heart leaped and then the person disappeared. I guess it was my mind, playing tricks on me. I cross a green-hued intersection, outside the Capulet storefront. Something is different about me. It‚Äôs like someone else is in charge. The crowd seems to part and flow around me. I gaze directly ahead, single-minded, without wavering. Outside the all-glass building, I look up. The glass walls rise three stories high. I stand there in the breezy, humid night. Inside I can see the guests at the reception. Now what? I‚Äôm not sure. But I have something to settle. Two empty wine bottles are standing by the curb. I grab one by the neck. It feels heavy in my hand. I hurl it immediately at the glass. It slams against the door, smashing the bottle into pieces. But the door stands intact, with only a thin, winding crack in the glass. I stand outside, fists clenched. Someone arrives rapidly at the door. I can‚Äôt see who they are, until the door swings open. It‚Äôs Tai. I didn‚Äôt think he‚Äôd actually be here. Behind him is a packed room of guests. Tai steps outside carefully, observing the crack in the door with amazement. He smiles proudly at me. ‚ÄúNot bad,‚Äù he says. I throw the second bottle at his head. Tai catches it in midair. He spins it to read the wine label, putting on impressed airs. What an asshole. I don‚Äôt know my next move. I just start walking toward him. I don‚Äôt know what Tai wants from me. But I want to get to the bottom of this. ‚ÄúNo Orion?‚Äù Tai observes. He sets down the wine bottle. I‚Äôm not afraid of Tai anymore. I walk straight up and take a swing at his head. My fist connects with his face. Tai bends downward, to the side. He doesn‚Äôt seem hurt. But that felt really good. For everything that he‚Äôs done. ‚ÄúWelcome home,‚Äù says Tai, recovering. He turns his back to me and walks inside. ‚ÄúCome on, Zu. I have something to show you.‚Äù I have no response. But I follow. In the low white ambience, the Capulet store is a cross between a royal palace and a mausoleum. From end to end are the most elegant-looking people in the brightest and boldest fashions. They smile pleasantly at me, as I pass. The whole place feels so beautifully decadent, like a futuristic garden of Eden. I kind of love it. But it‚Äôs definitely not me. Tai shoots me a mischievous wink. I pause momentarily. The door is still open behind me. I could always leave. But there‚Äôs something I need to know. Tai ascends a spiraling staircase. From behind him, I observe how his fist clenches, opening and closing again, as if he's in pain. Something about this gesture feels familiar. At the top of the stairs, I meet Lucrezia who wears a pretty white dress. She gives me a warm, sisterly smile. A frosted double door opens, and Tai and Lucrezia enter. I follow them across the threshold. The doors close behind me.

Scene 8.1 Delphine‚Äã Paris is in chaos. Smoke wafts over the narrow streets. I run, along with the others, from the other end of the avenue. The king‚Äôs soldiers are closing in, shouting at us. Our way is blocked by the barricades. I hear shots over my head. To my right is a doorway. I jam against it, but I can‚Äôt open it. Stenciled on the shop window are the words Des Arbres and a white tree. The soldiers are proceeding closer. I thrust my shoulder, with all my weight. On the third try, the door breaks open, unexpectedly. I fall inwards, onto the floor. My pistol tumbles across the shop. I look upward, from the floor. I am inside a furniture shop. Across the room is a young, blond-haired woman, holding my pistol. I stand up, defiantly. ‚ÄúGive me that,‚Äù I demand. ‚ÄúClose the door.‚Äù The gunfire outside is nearing. I turn quickly, forcing the wooden door back in place. I sweep my long, red-brown hair away from my face. ‚ÄúNow give me my pistol.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy, is it yours?‚Äù says the woman. She appears several years older than me, probably in her mid-twenties. She wears the comfortable brown dress of a shop merchant. ‚ÄúYes, it is,‚Äù I lie. ‚ÄúTo defend the nation.‚Äù I step forward aggressively, until the blond woman raises the pistol. ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt shoot me,‚Äù I defy her. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt think so?‚Äù Something in her tone makes me stop. Or perhaps, it is the deadly calm look in her blue eyes. There is something different about her. ‚ÄúWhat is your name?‚Äù ‚ÄúDelphine,‚Äù I say, proudly. The young, blond woman crosses the room, opening a drawer in a heavy cabinet. She places the pistol inside, locking it with a key. I barely contain my rage. ‚ÄúBe a villain, then,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúWhen they kill our sisters in the streets, you‚Äôll be to blame.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, there‚Äôs the door,‚Äù she says. Outside the soldiers are interrogating some of my friends in the street. ‚ÄúPerhaps I can stay,‚Äù I temper my voice, ‚Äúa little longer.‚Äù I‚Äôve been kicked out of my parents‚Äô house, and I actually have nowhere to go. But I don‚Äôt say this. The blond woman smiles. ‚ÄúI am trustworthy,‚Äù I assure her. She looks at me, piercingly. ‚ÄúWell, you can do some sweeping.‚Äù She hands me a broom. I take it, reluctantly. "And your name?‚Äù I ask. ‚ÄúTabithe.‚Äù Scene 8.2 Delphine‚Äã I stay with Tabithe that night. I remain awake, until I hear Tabithe sleeping. I go quietly to the cabinet. Carelessly, Tabithe has left the brass key lying on a nearby table. I open the locked drawer, retrieving my pistol. I find Tabithe in her bedroom. I point the pistol at her face, as she opens her eyes. ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt shoot me,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHow do you know?‚Äù I dare her. Her blue eyes regard me. ‚ÄúBecause, Delphine,‚Äù she says kindly, ‚Äúyou are a good person, at heart. And you care about people, even if you can‚Äôt always show it. And it would only add to the pain you already feel, every day.‚Äù I break down, sobbing. Scene 8.3 Delphine‚Äã Tabithe allows me to remain with her. We agree I can stay for one month. In return, I will help with her furniture shop. I don‚Äôt know why she would offer this, but I don‚Äôt care. Considering my parents won‚Äôt speak with me, the summer is sweltering and I don‚Äôt have much money, I consider this a good deal. I agree to give up the pistol, as insurance I won‚Äôt join in any more demonstrations. Well, why not? It‚Äôs not so bad. I grow to like Tabithe, even though she makes me work all day. And won‚Äôt answer half my questions. After a while, Tabithe has me greet her customers. I‚Äôm even learning about furniture. Ha! Tabithe and I have dinners together. She‚Äôs always asking me questions I don‚Äôt like to answer. Or don‚Äôt know how to answer. About myself or my family‚Äîor why I am angry. And when I do answer, she‚Äôll often just look at me. With those beautiful, clear blue eyes. She makes me curious about myself. In a way I haven‚Äôt been. We are changing a sofa upholstery, one afternoon, when I ask: ‚ÄúSo, why do you think I am defiant?‚Äù Tabithe drops her tools, looking at me. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs find out,‚Äù she smiles. Mysteriously. Scene 8.4 Delphine‚Äã We enter a room at the end of the hall. Through a doorway I barely knew was there. Inside is a small room, with a dusty skylight, but no windows. Tabithe sits on the floor, her dress spread around her. ‚ÄúSit across from me,‚Äù she motions. I sit down. ‚ÄúA bit closer,‚Äù she says. I inch forward, until I am within arms reach of Tabithe. Her beautiful blond hair falls below her shoulders. Her blue eyes smile at me. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to ask you a few questions,‚Äù she says. Oh, I‚Äôve heard this before! Tabithe smiles. ‚ÄúBut this time,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt have to answer. You just need to feel‚Äîwhatever you feel.‚Äù I am already uncomfortable. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù I agree. Tabithe looks to the door. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù she observes, ‚Äúyou must close the door.‚Äù I can‚Äôt see why. We are the only ones in the shop. Tabithe motions again to the door. I cross the room. ‚ÄúThis is not for everyone,‚Äù she says. I shut the door. Scene 8.5 Delphine‚Äã A blue light is filling the room. Tabithe smiles softly, raising her left palm. ‚ÄúNow is the fun part,‚Äù she says quietly. From above the skylight, the blue light descends. The room seems to disappear. Or, I disappear from it. I am aware of being in another time, or another place. I am another person, but it is also me. I am running. The sun is sharply overhead. I am larger and stronger, male. But just as confident in myself. And I am armed. But with a sword, not a pistol. Around me are others, with swords. We are in a sandy square, bright with sunlight on the buildings. I am bursting with anger. My friend tries to calm me, but a spearing pain ruptures my side. I collapse. Angrily, I raise myself. With my last breath, I shout: ‚ÄúA plague on both your houses!‚Äù My death has arrived. Only the blue light remains. Scene 8.6 Delphine‚Äã It‚Äôs a beautiful mid-July morning. Tabithe and I step out of the shop entrance, into the bright cobblestone street. People passing by wear red and blue ribbons, the colors of the revolution. Tabithe holds my arm, tenderly. She hands me the pistol. ‚ÄúAs we agreed,‚Äù she says. I am no longer the same furious girl, who broke down Tabithe‚Äôs door. I‚Äôve seen too much about myself, behind the closed door of the skylight room. I am different. ‚ÄúYou have helped me,‚Äù I say. It‚Äôs the understatement of my life. But I don‚Äôt have any other words. ‚ÄúIn the future,‚Äù Tabithe says, ‚Äúyou will have the chance to help someone too. To re-introduce them. The way I introduced you.‚Äù She sounds so specific. ‚ÄúWho?‚Äù I ask. ‚ÄúA friend,‚Äù says Tabithe, simply. I‚Äôve learned to accept her mysterious answers. We hear drums in the distance. There is an excitement in the air today. The militia is drawing through the streets, heading for the city center. ‚ÄúWhat now?‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs up to you.‚Äù I look into Tabithe‚Äôs eternally blue eyes. I kiss her on the cheeks. Then I join the growing crowd, marching toward the demonstrations. I can‚Äôt see my eyes. But I feel them blazing, calm and clear. Scene 8.7 Ori‚Äã Outside Hermes is waiting for me. The tree-lined avenue is ghostly quiet, as I approach my friend at the top of the entrance stairs. His eyes are blazing, calm and clear. ‚ÄúWhere is everyone?‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúI sent them home.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù Hermes stares at me, deeply. His eyes gaze toward me differently, more sharply. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something I want to show you, Ori,‚Äù he says. Scene 8.8 Zu‚Äã I follow Tai into the perfume lab. The room takes my breath away. It‚Äôs a cube shaped space, where the walls are covered in soft white light. The room seems to glow from within. Brightly colored perfume bottles adorn the tables. The glass bottles are round, oblong and dozens of even stranger shapes. I take a curious step forward. Surprisingly, I don‚Äôt smell a thing. I guess all the fragrance is trapped inside the bottles. Lucrezia comes up beside me. ‚ÄúPerfume has always been part of life,‚Äù she guides me toward a table of antique perfume bottles. ‚ÄúEven these bottles have a history.‚Äù She points to the bottle stoppers, ornately shaped as flowers, shells and animals. ‚ÄúThis one,‚Äù Lucrezia draws my attention to a dagger-like stopper, ‚Äúwas even used in the murder of a famous Italian noblewoman, sent to her death by a jealous lover.‚Äù She ushers me toward another table. On its surface are modern-looking vials. ‚ÄúDo you want to try?‚Äù Tai asks. I wrinkle my mouth, as if indifferent. I‚Äôm reminded how little I trust either of them. But at the same time, I am impressed being here. Lucrezia directs me toward a bottle filled with a light purple liquid. She places her hand on the lid. ‚ÄúThis is Evangeline,‚Äù she says. Lucrezia smiles, lifting the glass lid. She gently takes hold of my wrist. I debate whether I should pull away. How do I know it isn‚Äôt dangerous? I don‚Äôt. But I don‚Äôt care. The lab, the perfumes, whatever the purple Evangeline is. It‚Äôs all too captivating. A spray of purple mist moistens my wrist. Lucrezia nudges my hand toward my nose. For a long second or two, I hold my breath. Then I inhale. Oh, my goodness. I‚Äôve never smelled anything like this. It‚Äôs not just an aroma. It‚Äôs an all-senses experience. Without sorrows. Without feelings. It‚Äôs so powerful, it‚Äôs euphoric. But beneath the bliss, I feel I‚Äôm fighting for my life, fighting to remember who I am. Scene 8.23 Delphine‚Äã The smoke is pouring over the barricades. I leap forward, only to be thrown back, the force of a musket shot ripping through my shoulder. Scene 8.25 Delphine‚Äã ‚ÄúDelphine‚Äî‚Äù I imagine hearing my name. The air is thick with acrid smoke, but from where I lie, I can see the peaceful sky above. My eyes close. Scene 8.26 Zu‚Äã Kimmo parks outside the club. We get out nearly running. I follow Jaden and Aisha down into the basement building. We duck inside a doorway. Now there‚Äôs a bright blue sky, the wooden floor is turning to earth-colored stone. The table and comfortable sofas evaporate, revealing the canvas awnings and storefronts of the Piazza delle Erbe. I‚Äôve just stabbed Tybalt. My hatred of him rages in my veins. I smell Tybalt‚Äôs blood. Why am I remembering this? I never wanted to feel this way again. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt shy away, Ori,‚Äù I hear Hermes command. ‚ÄúThis is a part of you. Part of retrieval is remembering unpleasant things.‚Äù Tybalt shakes free of Adagio. ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt killed me,‚Äù says Tybalt, now in his own voice. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hardly a wound. Now fight!‚Äù Tybalt launches at me violently. I scamper away, dodging his blows raining down on me. Nothing of the beige room remains. It‚Äôs only the piazza and a fight to the death. ‚ÄúHermes!‚Äù I shout. Tybalt charges at me, barely missing. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only a memory, Montague,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be hurt.‚Äù Tybalt slams his sword hilt into my chest, knocking me down. A burning pain rips into my lungs. I gasp for air. ‚ÄúThat hurt‚Äî‚Äù I call out. Tybalt rages after me, attacking with his rapier. It cuts a swath through the wall of a building. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre reliving it, Ori,‚Äù says Tybalt, hammering me again. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs not real pain. It‚Äôs just the memory of the experience.‚Äù Tybalt smashes my jaw with the base of his sword. I collapse, tasting blood. I feel the jagged edge of a tooth, rolling on my tongue. I spit it out. ‚ÄúThis feels real,‚Äù I cough, my head splitting. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs because it was,‚Äù says Tybalt, arrogantly. ‚ÄúNow get up, Montague!‚Äù I feel fury, hearing my old name. My hatred of Tybalt is renewed. I labor to my feet, wielding Adagio. Tybalt attacks, but surprisingly, I repel him easily. We battle along the sun-caked storefronts of the Piazza delle Erbe. I‚Äôm using Adagio with a skill I‚Äôve forgotten. ‚ÄúFeel how your body moves,‚Äù Tybalt instructs, as he smashes a wooden pole to bits. ‚ÄúIn your movements, there is the memory, the knowledge of fighting‚Äîbut more importantly, the instinct and will to fight. That‚Äôs what you want to retrieve.‚Äù ‚ÄúLike this?‚Äù I clobber Tybalt backward with my forearm. He bleeds from his nose. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it,‚Äù he smiles. Tybalt beckons me on. We fight ferociously. I gain the upper hand, until Tybalt retakes it. I land two more punches to his face. ‚ÄúBe aware of every move,‚Äù Tybalt says, through his dirty, bleeding face. ‚ÄúYou can only retrieve what you feel. Feel how Adagio feels in your hand. Feel how you attack and defend, feel your stance, the way your feet move. But most importantly, feel how much you care! How much you would give‚Äîfor what you care about most!‚Äù Everything, I think. Tybalt slashes at me. He knocks me down, crushing his knee in my ribs. I roll to the side, dodging his killing blow. We rage on, metal to metal. I would give everything. I feel my sweat and hate. I swing away in unchecked fury, overwhelming Tybalt, until he can no longer defend himself. My next thrust skewers his flesh. Everything. Tybalt collapses, my sword in his side. He lifts his dying head. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôll do,‚Äù I hear Hermes‚Äô voice again. The Piazza delle Erbe wavers once, then disappears. The objects and tables of the beige room reform before my eyes. We‚Äôre standing in the exact position where we began. Hermes releases me from his grip. He‚Äôs not bloody or bleeding. And neither am I. Although my chest aches like fire. ‚ÄúMy friend,‚Äù Hermes says soberly, ‚Äúthat was beautiful.‚Äù Rays of sunshine fall on the wooden floor. ‚ÄúHow long has it been?‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúSeven hours,‚Äù Hermes checks his watch. ‚ÄúTime in retrieval is slower than time in the present.‚Äù He retakes Adagio from me, swinging it at my head. I duck and grab a broomstick. I sweep his legs with the broom, flipping Hermes to the ground. ‚ÄúI guess it worked,‚Äù he laughs. ‚ÄúBut how did we stand here?‚Äú I‚Äôm amazed. ‚ÄúFor seven hours?‚Äù Hermes picks himself up. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all part of the training,‚Äù he says simply. I want to ask more, but I don‚Äôt even know my question. ‚ÄúThis is about more than you and Zu,‚Äù Hermes says. ‚ÄúThe Montagues and Capulets are a small act in a much larger play.‚Äù He hands me Adagio, by the hilt. ‚ÄúSo what now?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWe find Zu.‚Äù Scene 9.6 Zu‚Äã When I wake, it‚Äôs morning. I lie in my bed. It feels like a morning, like any other. I brush my teeth, shower, and look in my closet. In the corner is a black dress that I never wear. I take it out. In the mirror, I look at myself. I lean forward, examining my eyes. Scene 9.7 Ori‚Äã I park my scooter outside Trinity Rose. Hermes and I approach the brownstone building. I haven‚Äôt set foot here since last year. It feels somewhat surreal, but I‚Äôm in my own world, and I hardly notice everyone‚Äôs eyes on me. We enter the main doors. I‚Äôm only here for Zu. But in the hallways, I can‚Äôt ignore the stares. Kids at open lockers stop what they‚Äôre doing, looking. I hear my name whispered, a dozen times. Ms. Hernandez, the principal, greets me, ‚ÄúGood to see you, Orion,‚Äù she smiles enthusiastically. I say hello, smiling and nearly stopping for her. But not quite. I can‚Äôt stop. For anyone. Not until I find Zu. I notice banners for The Lights, hung alongside the sides of the hallway. The Lights. Our third appointment. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only been one night,‚Äù I turn to Hermes. ‚ÄúOur timelines can‚Äôt be that split, right?‚Äù Hermes shrugs, uncertainly. We enter the student lounge. Groups of students are sitting around wooden tables, eating snacks and hanging out before class. Some of them look up. I can feel them watching. Sitting at a far table is Zu. She‚Äôs sitting with some friends, her head tilted downward. My heart lifts, just seeing her. It feels like ages, since last night. But there she is. Like always. Zu wears a black dress, which comes to a sharp end below her thigh. She doesn‚Äôt see me yet. Surrounding her are two girls I don‚Äôt know. Sitting beside them, for some reason, is Landon. I feel I‚Äôm seeing Zu for the first time. She‚Äôs talking in her easy, natural way. She brushes her purple hair, which covers her eyes, to one side. I reach her table. Zu turns to me. Her eyes are circled in dark eyeshadow. But it‚Äôs her gaze that makes me freeze. Something is so wrong. Zu is looking in my eyes. But without love. Without anything. ‚ÄúHey Ori,‚Äù she says. Her voice isn‚Äôt warm, or cold. It‚Äôs just empty. The way you would speak to someone you hardly know. I shift to my back foot. ‚ÄúZu‚Äî‚Äù I look in her eyes. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs me,‚Äù she replies. My stomach plummets. Is Zu trying to punish me? For last night? For running away? ‚ÄúI was hoping I‚Äôd find you here,‚Äù I explain, uncomfortably. Zu‚Äôs friends look toward her. ‚ÄúI guess you did,‚Äù she smiles. But it‚Äôs an empty smile. A smile for anyone. There‚Äôs an awkward pause at the table. I try to understand what‚Äôs happening. Zu doesn‚Äôt seem troubled. But it‚Äôs like she‚Äôs gone. Something has taken her place. ‚ÄúCan we talk alone?‚Äù I suggest. Zu‚Äôs friend with the tattoo observes me in a friendly way. I feel she‚Äôs on my side. ‚ÄúThese are my friends,‚Äù Zu says. ‚ÄúIf you want to say something, you can say it in front of everyone.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh‚ÄîI get it,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúThis is part of your rehearsal. For The Lights.‚Äù I look at Landon and almost laugh. I don‚Äôt really believe this. But it‚Äôs my only explanation. Neither Zu nor her friends say another word. I stand without moving, afraid to reveal my emotions. ‚ÄúWould you give us a moment?‚Äù I say to her friends. Now Landon is looking at me. ‚ÄúHey Ori‚Äî‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúShe said no.‚Äù I turn my head. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing here?‚Äù I say. Landon stares back. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing here?‚Äù he replies. Oh wow. Is this really happening? My eyes hurry from Landon to Zu. I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on here. But it feels so wrong. I hear one of Zu‚Äôs friends whisper to the other, ‚ÄúZu and Ori, or Zu and Landon?‚Äù Zu‚Äôs stare is frigid now. ‚ÄúIs Ori bothering you?‚Äù asks Landon. I‚Äôve had enough of him. ‚ÄúListen‚ÄîLandon,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what you think is happening, but just‚Äî‚Äú I pause, for the right words, ‚Äùshut up.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, Landon,‚Äù says Zu. I can‚Äôt believe my ears. I reach across the table, taking Zu by the hand. Incredibly, Landon grabs my arm. ‚ÄúHands off, Ori‚Äî‚Äù I seize Landon‚Äôs elbow, twisting hard. I drag him forward onto the tabletop, until his cheek is pressed down hard against the surface. I hold him down. I‚Äôm astonished. I can‚Äôt believe what I‚Äôve done. I‚Äôve never reacted this way in my life. This is the retrieval, I think to myself. My hands knew what to do. They remembered. Zu‚Äôs two friends look riveted. Everyone else in the lounge has stopped what they‚Äôre doing. They watch from their seats. Landon struggles on the tabletop. I tighten my hold to make him quiet. I don‚Äôt feel angry. Or any emotion at all. Only clear and calm. Ready to act. One of Landon‚Äôs friends comes toward me. Hermes places a hand on his chest, stopping him. Zu stares at me, over Landon‚Äôs slumped body. ‚ÄúI think you better leave, Ori,‚Äù she says. My strength empties out of me. Zu looks at me, as if I don‚Äôt matter. As if Landon doesn‚Äôt matter. As if nothing matters. She stares at me with a machine-like intensity. I glance at her bare wrists. ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the yarn?‚Äù I demand. ‚ÄúI lost it.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your problem?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs yours?‚Äù says Zu. ‚ÄúWe had a couple kisses. That doesn‚Äôt mean you own me.‚Äù ‚ÄúA couple kisses?‚Äù I repeat, unbelieving. This is too much. ‚ÄúHave you lost your mind?‚Äù Zu inhales tensely. ‚ÄúWe have things to do,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù ‚ÄúEverything we talked about!‚Äù Zu narrows her eyes. ‚ÄúThe Lights?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes!‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm helping Landon,‚Äù she says. I inhale fiercely. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just too romantic, Ori,‚Äù sighs Zu. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what they call a tragic flaw.‚Äù ‚ÄúTragic flaw?‚Äù I say, pressing down hard on Landon‚Äôs arm. I hear Landon whimper weakly. ‚ÄúWas kissing me on the High Line a flaw? Was Central Park a flaw? Was Verona a flaw? Was dying for each other a flaw?‚Äù It comes out like a cannon. Zu sits stone-like. I can feel she‚Äôs been reached. Even if she doesn‚Äôt show it. But the blankness remains. ‚ÄúIt was just a couple kisses,‚Äù she repeats. The fight drains out of me. I let go of Landon, who keeps his forehead low to the table anyway. I turn away from them, walking out of the lounge. Hermes catches me, quickly. ‚ÄúOri!‚Äù he grabs my arm. I shake him off. Scene 9.8 Zu‚Äã I watch as Ori leaves. I sense something significant has happened, but my expression doesn‚Äôt change. I sit motionless at the table. I feel an immediate urge to run after Ori, but it quickly passes. Instead, I tap two of my fingers on the table. One. After the other. I‚Äôm genuinely confused. What was Ori talking about? About dying for each other? It all felt so dramatic. But also so familiar. My two fingers keep tapping. ‚ÄúAre you okay, Zu?‚Äù says Kimmo. She seems concerned, which only bothers me more. ‚ÄúWhat was all that about Verona?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo idea,‚Äù I reply curtly. ‚ÄúOri seems like he really loves you,‚Äù says Kimmo. My fingers stop tapping. I‚Äôm staring down the hallway, where Orion just walked out. ‚ÄúHe seems cuter this year,‚Äù says Aisha. ‚ÄúHe seems like a bully,‚Äù says Landon. ‚ÄúShut up, Landon‚Äî‚Äú I say, surprising myself. I grab my backpack and tablet. I head straight for the hallway. Scene 9.9 Zu‚Äã I see Ori walking away, at the end of the hall. I hear a single locker shut, and then it's completely quiet. ‚ÄúAre you just leaving?‚Äù I say. Ori turns around. He walks deliberately toward me. I stand where I am. Around us a small group of kids closes in, forming a circle. Now we‚Äôre face to face. Ori looks at me. ‚ÄúAre you stopping me?‚Äù he says. Our eyes are inches apart. Neither of us move. I stare into Ori‚Äôs features. I sense something melting, far below my exterior. A series of images‚Äîtwo young people I don‚Äôt recognize‚Äîflash across my mind. My hands curl upward, slightly. But I can‚Äôt feel a thing. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I say. Scene 9.10 Zu‚Äã I watch Ori walking away. The door to Trinity Rose opens and closes. I‚Äôm left standing alone in the hallway. The kids around me have lost interest and dissolve. I stare at the tiled floor. Then I head off to class. I cross the lounge toward the stairs. I feel Kimmo, Aisha and Landon watching me. I slide my hand along the railing of the stairs. I can‚Äôt shake the sense I‚Äôve left something behind. And ugh. I still can‚Äôt smell a thing. Lauren‚Äôs class is on the second floor. When she sees me, she breaks away from another student. ‚ÄúWhere have you been?‚Äù Lauren looks worried. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been calling you.‚Äù ‚ÄúMy phone was on airplane.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou were supposed to come over,‚Äù Lauren says, with a scolding undertone. ‚ÄúWith Orion.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, right,‚Äù I knit my brow. This feels like ancient history. ‚ÄúI met up with some friends, we went dancing,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúI guess we got sidetracked.‚Äù Lauren has that same confused look that Ori did. ‚ÄúHow is Ori?‚Äù she asks. ‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs fine.‚Äù I shrug. ‚ÄúFine?‚Äù repeats Lauren. She obviously has more to say, but she leaves to start the class. I sit through Lauren‚Äôs lecture. Usually it‚Äôs my favorite class. But today it‚Äôs just meh. I enjoy what Lauren says about comedy‚ÄîI‚Äôm the only one who laughs out loud‚Äîbut the part on tragedy is a yawner. Lauren calls on me, but I have nothing to say. This seems to annoy her more. After class Lauren finds me, as I‚Äôm leaving. ‚ÄúZu!‚Äù Lauren practically shouts. She steps in front of me, blocking the door. I look strangely at Lauren. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just leave, Zu,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúTell me what happened.‚Äù ‚ÄúWith what?‚Äù I shake my head. ‚ÄúWith Orion,‚Äù Lauren answers. ‚ÄúWith the Capulets‚Äîwith everything!‚Äù The Capulets, right. The others students file past us. Lauren and I stand in the doorway, until we‚Äôre alone. ‚ÄúI went to see them,‚Äù I tell Lauren. ‚ÄúIt was after Ori got mad at me. They had a really cool lab.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou had an argument with Ori?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no biggie, Lauren,‚Äù I say. I edge past her into the hallway. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more fish in the sea.‚Äù Lauren looks furious. Why is everyone so agitated today? Now she‚Äôs following me down the hallway. It‚Äôs a little creepy, I won‚Äôt lie. ‚ÄúWhat else?‚Äù she demands. ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù I slow, reminded. ‚ÄúI spilled Nepenthe on myself.‚Äù Lauren‚Äôs eyes open wide. She places her arm in my path. ‚ÄúWe need to go see Orion,‚Äù she says. I duck around her again. ‚ÄúLauren, I have a class.‚Äù Scene 9.11‚Äã Beneath the brown buildings, a car carrying Tai and Lucrezia weaves through traffic. Tai rests against the headrest, his arms tightly across his chest. He suppresses a painful expression. ‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù Lucrezia asks him. ‚ÄúLast night looked difficult.‚Äù Tai doesn‚Äôt respond. ‚ÄúYou never mentioned your past with Juliet,‚Äù her eyes examine him. ‚ÄúHave you ever considered this trip might be personal for you?‚Äù ‚ÄúOf course it‚Äôs personal,‚Äú Tai snaps. Lucrezia looks defensive. ‚ÄúWell, maybe you could put that aside. At least for now.‚Äù Tai shakes his head. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs personal for you, too,‚Äù he says. Lucrezia knows he means her father. She hardens her lip. They enter the grey cobblestone streets of the Meatpacking District. Tai turns his head abruptly, toward the rear window. As if sensing something. ‚ÄúStop the car,‚Äù Tai tells the driver. He jumps out quickly into the street. Tai walks directly away from the car. ‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù Lucrezia exits the vehicle. Tai waves her away. ‚ÄúTai!‚Äù shouts Lucrezia. Ignoring her, Tai steps past pedestrians, looking left and right. He turns in a restless circle, then starts forward again, reading the street signs, looking around at the buildings and shops. He sees the sign for Gansevoort Street. His steps grow more sure. Across from the Whitney Museum, Tai stops as if he‚Äôs lost the scent. Finally, he looks directly upward. Above the corner restaurant is Ori‚Äôs studio. Scene 9.12 Zu‚Äã When I come out of history class, Hermes is waiting for me. I dodge my way around him. But I feel him following after me. Finally I whirl around. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äî‚Äú Hermes looks at me, directly. ‚ÄúI heard what you said to Lauren. In the hallway.‚Äù ‚ÄúAbout what?‚Äù ‚ÄúNepenthe.‚Äù I raise an eyebrow and begin walking away. ‚ÄúYou need to see Ori,‚Äù says Hermes. "I just saw him.‚Äù I am still walking away. ‚ÄúWait‚Äî‚Äù Hermes catches up. Hermes is standing in front of me. I step around him again. ‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Hermes says, playfully. ‚ÄúWhat do I have to do? I walk away again. ‚ÄúThree hundred,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù Scene 9.13‚Äã Tai ascends the stairwell of 71 Gansevoort, almost in a trance. Upon the third floor landing, he waits. He turns to the door on his right. Tai removes a small link from his necklace. In his fingers, it extends into a dark cylinder. He opens the lock with it. The door swings open, lazily. Inside is Ori‚Äôs studio. Tai eyes the workspace, with a mixture of envy and loathing. He steps silently through the rooms, examining the cluttered work table, the dress forms and racks. He sees the white dress. And walks toward it. Tai stands facing the dress. He wears an empty expression, remembering his life in Verona, his memories with Juliet, his death in the piazza. His heart darkens with hate for it all. He strokes the folds of the dress. Tai goes to the work table. He scans the tabletop, seeing swaths of fabrics, scissors, a handheld butane torch. Tai returns with the torch. He ignites the cloth of the dress. The fabric engulfs in fire. ‚ÄúTybalt‚Äî‚Äú Tai hears the shameful name. He whirls around, facing the voice. At the entrance of the studio is Orion. They stand facing each other, as the white dress burns.

Scene 3.1‚Äã VERONA, ITALY, PRESENT DAY‚Äã A black cat saunters up Via Dante Alighieri, a narrow alleyway in the heart of Verona. The walls of the buildings are striped, warmly red and white. The black cat picks a leisurely path in the sunlight. From the opposite direction, a boyish young person is approaching. He wears short, dark hair and a loose, black shirt and necklace. The two walk toward each other. In a few strides, they meet. The young person kneels on the stone alleyway, stroking the cat tenderly. It nestles among his legs, then continues on its way. The young person rises up, takes five steps and stops. As if stricken. They brace their left hand along the wall. Then slowly collapse to their knees. Their head bowed, eyes shut. One palm against the wall. Breathing. In their heart is a searing pain, mixed together with an excited, guilty pleasure. After many moments, they pull themselves to their feet. Quickly they exit the alleyway. They turn toward the Piazza delle Erbe, Verona‚Äôs main square. A marketplace of umbrellaed street vendors, fruit stands and tourists lies under a brilliant blue sky. Crossing the stone square, they circle the 700-year-old marble fountain of the Madonna of Verona. At the far end of the square, the young person enters a beautiful, three-story stone palazzo. Bolted onto the wall is a heavy bronze plaque. It reads: Capulet Verona Inside is a high glass atrium. Employees in red smocks circulate among customers, who examine small perfume bottles and exchange longing glances. On each bottle is stenciled the Capulet logo: a small white dagger. The person in black pays no attention. They move directly to the back of the floor room. Snippets of conversations catch their ears: ‚ÄúIt has a very fine head note.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd your most expensive fragrance?‚Äù ‚ÄúFor today‚Äôs woman, mandarin orange and sandalwood signal assertiveness and flexibility.‚Äù The young person approaches an elegant, double wooden door, which automatically slides open. Inside are men and women in white lab coats, busy at their stations. Everyone notices the young person, but no one meets their gaze directly. The young person walks past, up a spiraling, marble staircase. Two stylish employees are descending. They nod and say, ‚ÄúMaestro.‚Äù At the third-floor landing is a heavy door. The young person clenches their right hand, before reaching out and turning the knob. Statues and old books fill the room. Toward the edge of the room, a wall-sized display comes to life. Appearing on the screen is an elderly Asian man, seated with his hands clasped. The person in black walks directly toward the screen. He raises his eyes. ‚ÄúJuliet is back,‚Äù he says. Gradually, the older man lifts his eyebrows, leaning slowly forward. ‚ÄúAre you certain, Tai?‚Äù he says, a mix of curiosity and caution. The young person rubs their right hand. ‚ÄúHer signature is unmistakable, uncle,‚Äù he says. The older man stares gravely at Tai. ‚ÄúDo I need to remind you how important this is?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve waited for over five hundred years.‚Äù ‚ÄúBelieve me,‚Äù Tai stares back. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù Scene 3.2 (unnamed)‚Äã I hurry up the hilltop. Verona lies below me, outstretched in red brown rooftops, curving beyond the Adige River. Through the white, quickly moving clouds, the sunshine brightens and fades along the hillside. Ahead of me is Castel San Pietro, an imposing walled fortress commanding the city. I lift the ends of my blue dress, cutting across the high grass. I came as quickly as I could. But I'm already late. I reach the overlook, the place we are supposed to meet. The young boy stands under a wide tree, his back to me, gazing in contemplation or dream, across our home city of Verona. I approach, with a determined step. Ah, he senses I am here! He turns around. Scene 3.3‚Äã Tai re-enters the perfume lab, where the technicians in white coats hurry back and forth. He heads toward a young woman with platinum hair. ‚ÄúLucrezia‚Äî‚Äù he calls ahead. The young woman pretends not to hear. She dabs a thin paper strip into a bottle of red perfume. She waves the paper under the nose of another young technician. His eyes are blindfolded. ‚ÄúDaffodils,‚Äù he smiles. Lucrezia switches smelling strips, testing a second perfume, this one a slightly deeper red. The young man changes expressions. He appears to be recalling something. ‚ÄúSeashells,‚Äù he says curiously. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù says Lucrezia. ‚ÄúBut when?‚Äù The young man concentrates. He swallows. ‚ÄúOn the beach, with my mother. I was twelve, no, eleven‚Äîwhen I was eleven.‚Äù Tai watches the experiment, impatiently, his arms folded. Lucrezia places a third paper strip under the young man‚Äôs nose, the deepest red of all. ‚ÄúAnd this one?‚Äù she asks. The young man inhales deeply. Almost immediately he recoils, his face contorting, as if escaping from the scent. A line of perspiration appears on his brow. ‚ÄúI‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he answers, nervously. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt I tell you?‚Äù Tai interrupts Lucrezia‚Äôs experiment. ‚ÄúNo negative memories. Who wants a perfume to feel terrible?‚Äù Lucrezia casts a downward eye. The technician removes his blindfold. Lucrezia puts away the perfume and pats him on the arm. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay,‚Äù she says gently. ‚ÄúYou did really well.‚Äù She swivels toward a ruby-colored light, hovering on the tabletop. ‚ÄúDid you get that, RITA?‚Äù she says. The ruby light wavers in a pleasant, female voice, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre getting closer, Lucrezia.‚Äù Tai pulls Lucrezia away from the table. ‚ÄúYou and I are taking a little trip,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúNow?‚Äù she asks. ‚ÄúAdesso‚Äî‚Äù Tai repeats loudly, walking away. Lucrezia glances at her lab table, littered with small glass vials and testing strips. RITA wavers in red, ‚ÄúSafe travels, Lucrezia.‚Äù Tai has already disappeared down the hall. Lucrezia rushes to catch him, removing her lab coat. They step into a sun-drenched courtyard. A dark sedan and a driver are waiting for them.
