A hint of stars appears above the translucent studio ceiling. ‚ÄúI think‚Äî‚Äú Zu struggles. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre at my house.‚Äú We‚Äôre half in the studio, half in Verona. ‚ÄúSomeone‚Äôs coming,‚Äù says Zu. I hear a woman‚Äôs voice: ‚ÄúJuliet!‚Äù The stone house is taking form. Lush flowers weave along a trellis above our heads. ‚ÄùMy heart is beating," Zu says. ‚ÄúI feel excited.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat else do you feel?‚Äù Zu squints, as if her vision is blurry. ‚ÄúI‚Äî‚Äù she says, uncertainly, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel anything else.‚Äù The retrieval is beginning to reverse. Alarmingly, I watch the stone house and stars fading away. The solid, brick walls of the studio are returning. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs okay,‚Äù I say, trying to keep calm. ‚ÄúStay with it. What you were feeling about us?‚Äù Zu shakes her head. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gone,‚Äù she says. The stone house is a rapidly retreating memory, beyond the studio walls. We‚Äôre quickly losing our link to Verona. I seize Zu‚Äôs hand in mine. ‚ÄúLet me help,‚Äù I say. Zu grips my hand instinctively. I restart the retrieval, using my own feelings as the thread. The process feels easier, every time I engage it. Like a path I‚Äôve walked before. Immediately, the studio walls soften. With our hands locked together, the stone house reappears once again. This time it‚Äôs more rapid, more visceral. I experience the sharp sounds, the sweet odors and colors of a party in Verona, five hundred years ago. The canopy of stars is brighter than any I remember. Only the faintest outline of the Gansevoort studio remains. ‚ÄúAre you with me?‚Äù Zu nods. The stone house is completely solid. We‚Äôre below the wooden trellis, overlooking the gardens. My heart is racing, someone is coming. My arms are covered in fine, 16th-century cloth. But Zu looks the same. The same as in New York City. She wears the same black dress. The same dark eyeshadow. And the appearance of her skin, here in Verona, is transparent. She can‚Äôt enter into the past. She‚Äôs stuck in the present. I grip her hand tightly. ‚ÄúZu, you need to feel this,‚Äù I say desperately. ‚ÄúYou need to feel what happened!‚Äù Everything depends on this. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt.‚Äù ‚ÄúTry!‚Äù Zu holds my gaze and hand. But I feel Nepenthe blocking her. Someone is approaching from the house, searching for us. I feel the rush of this moment, our first meeting. I try to pull Zu toward me, into the past, with my cloth-covered arms. But her hands are disappearing. I can no longer hold them. Her gaze drifts lower. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt feel it,‚Äù she resigns. Instantly, the images of the stone house, the garden flowers, and the party begin packing up. The ceiling replaces the beautiful sky, and the brick walls block out the Verona night. Zu and I sit facing each other, in our street clothes. The retrieval is over. It failed. I sit back, shaken. Zu unclasps her hand from mine. I feel I‚Äôm sitting opposite a stranger. Zu gazes at me with as much feeling as a glass of water. I look ahead, stunned. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù she says, apologizing for me. ‚ÄúI know you wanted that to work.‚Äù She turns to Hermes. ‚ÄúCan we go now?‚Äù I‚Äôm shocked. We can‚Äôt end this way. Not after everything. Not like this. I get up, grabbing a vase of flowers. I toss out the flowers, throwing the water on Zu‚Äôs face. ‚ÄúAh, wha‚Äî?‚Äù she sputters. ‚ÄúSeriously?‚Äù She gasps in shocked surprise. Zu lowers her head, breathing. Was a shock all she needed? Hermes and I lean forward, eagerly. ‚ÄúDo you feel any differently?‚Äù I ask. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm wet,‚Äù Zu reacts angrily. She grabs her backpack. ‚ÄúHave a nice afternoon,‚Äù she says, barely acknowledging me. She heads across the studio toward the door. I‚Äôm left with Hermes. Something inside me snaps. Scene 10.10 Ori‚Äã I catch her in the stairwell. I hardly know what I‚Äôm doing. I grab Zu by the hand. She pulls back sharply, but I don‚Äôt let go. I start up the stairwell, pulling Zu behind me. She‚Äôs shouting something. I don‚Äôt hear her words. We ascend the stairs, crashing against the concrete walls. Zu pulls backward against me. But I don‚Äôt stop. I throw open the door to the roof. The sunlight blazes into us. I step through the door. Zu has a wild look in her eyes. I cross the bare rooftop, dragging Zu behind me. I feel enraged and crazed. Like there‚Äôs nothing left to do. Zu resists, beating at my arms and my chest, my head. ‚ÄúLet go!‚Äù she is yelling. ‚ÄúLet go of me!‚Äù I keep moving, forward. I sense what I‚Äôm about to do. But it‚Äôs too terrible to say. We cross the rooftop, battling. I head straight for the ledge. ‚ÄúWhat are you going to do?‚Äù Zu practically dares me. ‚ÄúThrow us off?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù I shout back. The ledge is twenty feet away. I drag us onward. ‚ÄúGo ahead,‚Äú Zu cries out. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt remember, okay? Whatever it is you want me to feel‚ÄîI don‚Äôt feel it,‚Äù Zu is nearly crying. ‚ÄúSo just do it!‚Äù I shut my eyes, moving toward the ledge. I look straight down, to the black cars below. We‚Äôve done this before. We died before, when there was no more hope. What‚Äôs so different now? We can‚Äôt live like this. We know how to do this. The past repeats, said Lauren. I stand on the narrow raised ledge. Zu no longer resists me. She looks into the street. The roof drops three stories straight down. All we have to do is jump. I‚Äôm not afraid. We‚Äôve done this before. I hold Zu‚Äôs hand, tenderly. One more step is all we need. My weight would send us over. I‚Äôm picturing it happening. The two of us falling, hand in hand. I‚Äôm staring down into the street. The pavement feels so close. It would only take a second. Then we‚Äôd be together. Again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Zu is crying. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I can‚Äôt remember!‚Äù We can‚Äôt live like this. The past repeats, said Lauren. I step gently forward, along the ledge. Toward the corner of the building. Zu steps backward, looking in my eyes the whole time. We‚Äôre nearing the corner. She isn‚Äôt fighting anymore. Zu nods her head slowly. Without words. Her eyeshadow is smeared. Her eyes try to reach me, but behind some veil. Behind Nepenthe. I feel I‚Äôm watching someone underwater, sinking slowly out of sight. Her lips move, but no words come out. Every step quickens my resolve. The corner is ten feet away. I push us toward it. The sunlight blinds our eyes. I hear horns from the street below. We‚Äôre in this together. I can see it behind Zu‚Äôs eyes. She can‚Äôt remember. But somehow she agrees. ‚ÄúDo it, Ori,‚Äù she whispers. We‚Äôve reached the corner. I see the intersection below on both sides. ‚ÄúDo it,‚Äù she says. I don‚Äôt hesitate. I take another step, Zu steps backward. A cluster of pigeons bursts up above us. Zu swivels, avoiding the birds. Her foot misses the ledge. Zu‚Äôs knee crashes upon the ledge. Her weight pulls me down, toward her. Toward the intersection below. I collide into Zu on the corner of the ledge. We‚Äôre smashed together at the edge of the building. It‚Äôs our last chance. I kiss Zu, with everything I have. The streets are still moving, below us. But we have stopped. Every hope and memory of the past and future is passing between our locked lips. The Capulet garden in Verona appears one last time. I am there with Zu. But something has changed. Zu is dressed in her black dress, but she‚Äôs no longer transparent. Her skin is the color of flesh. We look on each other, like newborns. Our eyes have never known love before. In the warm floral night, we tremble in the garden. One of us reaches out. In Verona, I am kissing Zu. For the first time. The New York skyline is fading fast. Below the rooftops, the traffic starts and stops and starts again. Lights wink on across the city. In the Capulet garden, something is happening. My hands hold firmly on Zu‚Äôs dress. But the fabric below my fingers is changing. It‚Äôs no longer modern, no longer black. I feel the softness of Juliet‚Äôs purple silk dress. Zu‚Äôs hands press warmly into mine. Our lips are sealed. This is where we began. We are, as we were. On the Gansevoort rooftop, time passes. The moon arcs upward in the sky, a pale reflection on the river. I am kissing Zu on the rooftop. Something is surfacing, inside her. I feel Zu‚Äôs fingers around my neck. Her body shakes, like she‚Äôs gasping for air. Like she‚Äôs rising from the dead. But Nepenthe won‚Äôt let go. I feel Zu being torn in two, between forgetfulness and memory. She‚Äôs somewhere between drowning and gasping for life. Between a wail and roar. In Verona, one whole second has passed. If time even passes at all. I am kissing Zu in the garden, in her purple silk dress. Back in New York City, the lights checker the night. The traffic races through the streets below, in trailing red and white lights. Slowly the lights come to a stop. Our kiss comes to an end. Beyond us is the green garden in the night, forever innocent. This moment, saved in the Verona stars. We are, as we were.

ZU is an imaginative 16-year-old from Hong Kong and the reincarnation of Juliet Capulet. Reflective and curious about her identity and the world around her, she spends mornings drawing on her tablet as she adjusts to New York and her new school. An aspiring artist and storyteller, she has a power at her core she is only beginning to tap.

ORI is a talented, enigmatic 17-year-old and the reborn Romeo Montague. Precocious and creative, he is the subject of attention and gossip at Trinity Rose, but little understood. Originally from L.A., he has never quite adapted to New York, nor recovered from the early death of his sister. He is most comfortable in the company of his best friend Hermes.

HERMES is an 11th-grader and the reincarnated Mercutio. Humbled and enlightened by an intermediary life in Revolutionary France, Hermes is a Montague Initiate tasked with guiding Zu and Ori toward their destiny. Brilliant, loyal, irreverent, street-smart, fearless, and prophetic: Hermes is all of these and more.

TAI is the reborn Tybalt Capulet. Domineering and driven, he is the creative face of the House of Capulet. As a projection of his past sufferings, he creates the pain-erasing perfume Nepenthe. Wounded and rageful to the core, Tai dresses in black and yearns for a reunion with Zu, his sister in his Verona life.

PROFESSOR LAUREN is a young teacher at Trinity Rose and the reincarnated Friar Lawrence. Unaware of her past life, Lauren is naturally drawn to both Zu and Orion, going out of her way to assist each of them. Deeply caring and possessed of easy-going wisdom, she feels a subconscious guilt for her role in Romeo and Juliet‚Äôs deaths and seeks to redeem herself.

Scene P.1 Ori‚Äã There‚Äôs a knock at my door. I walk across the studio, open it. Zu gives me a look. ‚ÄúReady?‚Äù she says. I grab my bag, we head down the stairs together. Outside on Gansevoort we look across to the High Line, watching the traffic move up and down the street. Zu smiles, as I tap my phone. I enter a location. The ride choices appear. I glance at them, and without hesitating, I choose Share. Within a minute our Uber arrives. Zu and I recline in the backseat, closely together. She‚Äôs wearing a white printed t-shirt and black jeans, and I‚Äôve borrowed one of Hermes‚Äô jersey pullovers. We‚Äôre watching New York City outside the windows. I tap a notification on my screen, as Zu leans into me. A news video begins playing: ‚ÄúIn fashion news, Nepenthe, the latest fragrance from the House of Capulet, has become the biggest hit in the company‚Äôs storied history. But the so-called ‚Äúfeel-good fragrance‚Äù isn‚Äôt quite what people expected. Billed as the end of suffering, customers say Nepenthe is more like a leisurely walk in the park.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs the bottom line that matters. The House of Capulet appears stronger than ever.‚Äù ‚ÄúIn a related story, memorials are being held for Tai Fang, creative director of the House of Capulet. As you know, Tai Fang was killed backstage at the Trinity Lights benefit this weekend. Details are still murky, but his creative heir Lucrezia de Rosa has been taken into custody. The question on everyone‚Äôs mind now: Who will lead the company?‚Äù I move to switch it off, but Zu grabs my hand. ‚ÄúOn another note,‚Äù the announcer continues, ‚Äúa performance at the same Trinity Lights event has gone viral. A re-make of Romeo and Juliet by two Trinity Rose high-schoolers has hit 100 million views across social media platforms.‚Äù The video cuts to a short snippet of Zu, bent over my body on the stage. ‚ÄúViewers say the students captured the timeless magic of the famous lovers in a deeply moving way.‚Äù We watch a reporter talking. ‚ÄúThe performance has even sparked an urban myth,‚Äù she looks into the camera, ‚Äúthat Nepenthe stops working once you watch the video.‚Äù The screen shows a social media post: ‚ÄúY‚Äôall Nepenthe was fine, til I watched this video üò≠üò≠üòÇ #feelit‚Äù I swipe off the app. I put my phone away and we‚Äôre both silent. Zu looks at me and I look at her. We have no words. ‚ÄúHow are you doing?‚Äù I ask. Zu looks out the window, then at me. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good,‚Äù she nods, then smiles. We pass an intersection, where our Uber pulls toward the curb. A woman in a white jacket joins our ride, climbing into the front passenger seat. She has a striking presence. For a block or so, Zu and I observe her from behind. The woman turns around casually. ‚ÄúI saw your performance,‚Äù she says, with clear, piercing eyes. ‚ÄúIt really spoke to my heart.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh,‚Äù says Zu, surprised, ‚Äúthanks.‚Äù I am captivated by her presence. Her eyes seem to radiate with clarity and purpose. ‚ÄúI was looking around the audience,‚Äù the woman in white looks at Zu. ‚ÄúI think you touched some people.‚Äù ‚ÄúI wanted to,‚Äù Zu says, honestly. ‚ÄúWell, consider me a fan,‚Äù the woman smiles. She hands us a white card, which Zu takes. ‚ÄúMy name is Santiaga. Look me up, if I can ever be of service.‚Äù She gives us a friendly glance. Our Uber pulls toward the sidewalk again, and Santiaga quickly steps out. We‚Äôve hardly traveled five blocks together. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt have far to go,‚Äù she winks at us, before literally disappearing in the busy New York street. I look back out the window as we accelerate, sensing something important has happened. But what? ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no writing,‚Äù Zu says. She flips over the card. On the back side is an embossed white tree. Zu moves her thumb over the texture. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs pretty,‚Äù she turns to me. I look down at the tree. We‚Äôve arrived at Trinity Rose. I look out at the school, feeling weird butterflies in my stomach. ‚ÄúI hate Mondays,‚Äù I sigh. Zu gives my hand a squeeze, then turns up her lip. ‚ÄúA deal is a deal,‚Äù she says. We get out together, on the same side, then head toward the school. I see Hermes and Kimmo, standing by the entrance. Some of the other kids are starting to notice us. They are gathering around. We go toward them.

Scene 11.1 Tai‚Äã I remember that day. It was a normal day, in every other way. I was in the backseat, gazing forward through the windows, as my father drove. My mother sat beside my father, talking. I listened to their voices from the backseat. But today, their voices seemed more distant. I had just been told I was adopted. A thin canopy of trees covered the winding road, the sharp mountains in the distance. My mother was turning her head to me. The accident happened so fast. Was it the car beside us? I no longer remember what happened. I only remember after the impact. The broken windshield. The smell of rubber, chemicals, oil. Of burnt plastic. The smell of blood. It was suddenly quiet. I sat in the backseat, alone. My parents did not move. I remember all of this. My mother‚Äôs head hung down, her beautiful hair over her shoulders, as always, as the blood streaked down the side of her face. I shouted at her. My voice was so loud, in the silence. I believe I scared myself. Because I should have kept shouting. That would have been normal. But instead I became quiet, and I just stared at the two of them, the two dead people who had always loved me. Who I thought had been my parents. I stayed unmoving, a patch of forest around the car, until the police arrived. I didn‚Äôt even undo my seat belt. Scene 11.2 Tai‚Äã I went to live with my uncle. I was taken to the grounds where he lived, in a chauffeur driven car. I sat in the backseat, alone. My uncle‚Äôs residence was a grand building, with two large wings. It seemed like a palace to me. My uncle greeted me. I remember his words. He placed his bony hand on my shoulder, and said, ‚ÄúThis is your new home, Tai.‚Äù And he took me inside. This would be my home, for the next seven years. My uncle was well-known for running a distinguished perfume business. His name was Fang An. And his company was called Zhu Perfume. Which I got to know, intimately. I had never been much interested in perfume, despite my keen sense of smell. But at my uncle‚Äôs home, it was all anyone spoke about. The different fragrances, what they meant, how they should be used. It was like a religion. What perfume meant to life. Inevitably, what was always said was, ‚Äúperfume helps us to remember.‚Äù But I did not want to remember. Scene 11.3 Tai‚Äã I began my training. On top of my regular schooling, in which perfection was expected, I studied with my fragrance instructor, Li, several hours a day. Colorless liquids were placed in front of me. I was expected to name them. And not only their names, but their attributes and relationships. Punishment for failure was swift. A stern scolding for my first mistake. A wooden spatula for my second. And worse for a third. But they achieved their result. At a young age, I became something of a prodigy in the art of fragrance. My uncle was very proud of me. But not always. One particular night, we met together in the ornate perfume hall. I was to create my own fragrance, ideally resembling one of the Zhu masterpieces. My uncle and Li stood by, watching attentively. I began with ambergris and vanilla, and a bit of tonka bean to round it off. I saw their faces brighten, as they sniffed the preparation. I was doing as I had been taught. But I had learned other things too. On my own. I retrieved the trial perfume from Li. To this, I added a brush of starflower. I knew what this would do. I had noticed that certain fragrances could mask the powerful memory effects of perfume. I was excited by this. But my instructor‚Äôs face went blank. ‚ÄúNo, Tai,‚Äù said Li. ‚ÄúWe want to evoke memories, not make them go away.‚Äù By his tone, I knew he meant the conversation was over. My uncle stared at me harshly, but did not speak. I debated my next move. ‚ÄúBut why?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat is our way‚Äî‚Äù my uncle interjected. ‚ÄúFor centuries, the Zhu perfumes have allowed people to remember what they have forgotten.‚Äù ‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù I protested, ‚Äúit‚Äôs time for a new way.‚Äù My uncle‚Äôs face turned granite. I had crossed a line. He dragged me to the washing room of the servants, where I was beaten with a black rod. Again. And again. Until I bled. So I had another memory to forget. But also a new motivation. Scene 11.4 Tai‚Äã On my fifteenth birthday, I learned my uncle‚Äôs company had purchased the famous House of Capulet. It was a celebratory day in my uncle‚Äôs house. I was to be sent to Verona. To eventually take over. My uncle called me into his study. ‚ÄúTai, this is a great honor,‚Äù he said warmly. ‚ÄúWe have a long history with the House of Capulet. We‚Äôll be entrusting you with an important position.‚Äù I stood quietly, but proudly. ‚ÄúAre you aware,‚Äù my uncle eyed me, carefully, ‚Äùof the prophecy?‚Äù My eyes widened. So the rumors were true! ‚ÄúYou mean, about Juliet Capulet,‚Äù I said, trying to sound knowledgeable, ‚Äúand the red perfume.‚Äù That was our name for the fabled past-life perfume. The ageless goal of the Capulets and Zhus. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äú my uncle nods. He folded his hands together. ‚ÄúBut Juliet won‚Äôt find us on her own,‚Äù he told me. ‚ÄúShe will need to be guided.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow?‚Äù I am confused. ‚ÄúBy someone close to her." My uncle leaned back in his chair. ‚ÄúI have watched you closely‚Äîfor many years‚ÄîTai,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs something I need to know.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnything, uncle.‚Äù My uncle laughed, once. He opened his desk drawer, slowly. ‚ÄúUnfortunately, you can‚Äôt tell me, Tai,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBecause you don‚Äôt know.‚Äù He placed an antique bottle of red liquid on the desk. ‚ÄúBecause you don‚Äôt remember.‚Äù ‚ÄúIs that the red perfume?‚Äù I gaped. ‚ÄúAn imperfect version.‚Äù I stood speechless. Until this meeting, I hadn‚Äôt been sure the red perfume existed. The grail of all memory perfumes, it was more of a myth than reality. The red bottle was pushed toward me. ‚ÄúWould you like to try it?‚Äù I froze. I had heard all the warnings, of course. Of insanity, and worse, for those who inhaled the red perfume. But I also had a personal fear. I was afraid to remember my past. ‚ÄúRespectfully, uncle,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúI decline.‚Äù A violent flash of anger crossed my uncle. I had seen this in him before. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be selfish, Tai,‚Äù he shamed me. ‚ÄúPut your family before yourself.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo‚Äîuncle.‚Äù I was terrified of my past. ‚ÄúYou refuse me?‚Äù he said, furiously. My uncle stepped around his desk, surprising me with his agility. ‚ÄúDisrespectful person!‚Äù he shouted. ‚ÄúAfter everything this family has given you.‚Äù He grabbed my head, pushing me to the floor. My uncle opened the red bottle. He forced it to my nose. ‚ÄúYou will remember,‚Äú he said. And I did. Painfully. Scene 11.5 Tai‚Äã I liked Verona, immediately. Of course by then, I understood why. But it didn‚Äôt really matter. When you are home, you‚Äôre home. Even though my memories were unfortunate, I still took pleasure in returning to the places I had enjoyed, so long ago. In particular, the fountain in the Piazza della Erbe. Where I once played. Also, I could now work on my own, without my uncle and Li watching over me. I felt others were beginning to see me, and respect me, for myself. And I had chosen a color. For my perfume. Green. Scene 11.6 Tai‚Äã In one of our video conferences, my uncle surprised me. ‚ÄúTai,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve hired someone to work with you. She‚Äôll be leading our memory work.‚Äù Immediately the door opened. A girl with dark brown hair entered. She walked up to me, glancing in my eyes, momentarily. ‚ÄúThis is Lucrezia,‚Äù said my uncle. ‚ÄúI prefer Lu,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve selected her,‚Äù my uncle continued proudly, ‚Äúafter a long search. From now on, you‚Äôll work together. She will be your assistant.‚Äù We regard each other, sideways. ‚ÄúAs you know, Tai,‚Äù said my uncle, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not fond of your oblivion perfume. But I‚Äôm going to allow it. In return for bringing Juliet back.‚Äù I looked down at the floor. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard you remember your past,‚Äù Lucrezia said to me. ‚ÄúI would like to, also.‚Äù I inhaled shortly. I never liked being reminded of this. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be so sure,‚Äù I said. Scene 11.7 Lauren‚Äã I hurry up the Gansevoort stairs. I‚Äôve brought Kimmo with me, after she came to my classroom, worried about Zu. Hermes has been messaging me all afternoon. About my car, opera and Shakespeare. Nepenthe and bubble tea. His statements don‚Äôt make sense. It all makes me anxious. The lock on the door is smashed. I walk in, with Kimmo right behind me. The studio lies in shambles. Orion and Zu stand in the middle of the room. With blank expressions. Scene 11.8 Zu‚Äã Orion and I face the others. We look like zombies after the apocalypse. Ori‚Äôs shoulder is matted and caked with blood, a maroon stain sits on his sleeve. My black eyeshadow is smeared down my face. I am missing a shoe. A half dozen eyes are searching us. Lauren and Kimmo stand in the doorway, Hermes is on the sofa. Neither Ori or I say a word. I exhale, taking a deep breath. From across the studio, I smell the jasmine scent of Kimmo‚Äôs presence, the sweet dry cloth of cotton, the metal electricity of the overhead lighting, and the slow humid air wafting in the windows. I breathe in Ori‚Äôs pewter sandalwood. And dozens of other scents. Behind each one is a memory. At once, I‚Äôm reminded of my first visit to Ori‚Äôs studio, and of lunches in elementary school. Of meeting Ori. In Verona. Every fragrance is a memory. Lauren comes up to me, uncertainly. ‚ÄúLauren,‚Äù I smile at her, ‚Äúyou smell like roses.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou can smell again?‚Äù says Lauren. ‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúHow?‚Äù ‚ÄúOri brought me back,‚Äù I say simply. I take another breath. ‚ÄúHe made me feel again.‚Äù I‚Äôm still adjusting. I‚Äôm halfway between the slow-motion time of Verona and the normal present. But something of Verona has returned with me. There‚Äôs a starry purple glitter, hovering around Orion and I. I can‚Äôt actually see it. But I can feel it. The others are gathering closer. Hermes is holding a dustpan and broom. I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm back. Or that I went away. Everything is back. Ori and Verona. My memories, my love. For everything. For Orion. Like waking from a dream. A dream without love. We stand together, in the starry glitter. ‚ÄúNepenthe isn‚Äôt just about forgetting,‚Äù I explain to Lauren. ‚ÄúIt stops you from loving. If you can‚Äôt feel anything‚Äî you can‚Äôt love anyone!‚Äù If only I had known. I‚Äôd never have been tempted. ‚ÄúSo what are you gonna do?‚Äù asks Kimmo. ‚ÄúAbout what?‚Äù ‚ÄúNepenthe‚Äî‚Äù I hadn‚Äôt considered doing anything. I‚Äôve barely made it back myself. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt it come out tomorrow?‚Äù Kimmo says, awkwardly. Scene 11.9 Ori‚Äã I turn toward Zu. Our starry Verona dust still lingers. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs one more thing,‚Äù I say, ‚Äúwe need to do.‚Äù She replies, without thinking. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou do?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Lights,‚Äù she says. I feel our connection in her words. We‚Äôre on the same page. Lauren turns toward us, overhearing. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tomorrow night, you know,‚Äù she says. I am watching Lauren, carefully. She steps forward, eagerly, ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre thinking about it, I could save you a spot. If you like,‚Äù Lauren holds out both her hands, outstretched. I am seeing something. Slowly. He hides his gaze, avoiding me. We stand in the courtyard of the Capulet mansion. ‚ÄúTybalt‚Äî‚Äú I approach him tenderly, ‚ÄúI never meant to hurt you. A sister‚Äôs love. ‚ÄúI cared for you, when you were a baby,‚Äù Tybalt says, clenching his fist. ‚ÄúAnd then you left us.‚Äù ‚ÄúI know. I‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù I say genuinely. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt mean I didn‚Äôt love you.‚Äù Tybalt winces at my words. Now I understand. This is personal. This isn‚Äôt really about Nepenthe. That‚Äôs not why I‚Äôm here. This is about Tybalt and me, about the pain and misunderstandings of our past. Now there‚Äôs a chance to change this. To save Tybalt from his hate. That‚Äôs the reason I‚Äôm here. All I can do is tell the truth. ‚ÄúYes, I left you,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúI left too soon. But it was out of love.‚Äù ‚ÄúLove,‚Äù Tybalt snorts. But I feel he wants to understand. To open to me. ‚ÄúYes, I was born a Capulet,‚Äù I continue moving toward Tybalt. ‚ÄúBut I chose another way. I chose another life. But I chose it‚Äîit was my choice.‚Äù I feel every word I am saying, observing how Tybalt responds. ‚ÄúNow it‚Äôs your choice‚Äîto forgive me, or not. ‚ÄúForgive?‚Äù says Tybalt, like it‚Äôs a foreign word. ‚ÄúYes, forgive,‚Äù I say with all my heart. ‚ÄúForgive me for what I‚Äôve done. That‚Äôs all you have to do. Please, please forgive me.‚Äù I place my hand on his arm. Tybalt is trying to resist letting me in. But he wants to. Because I am Juliet, his sister. I am standing before him. I can smell the Verona earth and terra-cotta of the Capulet courtyard. I can see every wisp of Tybalt‚Äôs hair, in crystal clarity. There is so much beauty in him, beneath all of his hardened hate. Tybalt looks at me lovingly. There is a gentleness in his gaze. I hold out my hand. He reaches out, grasping it. His grip is tight, but underneath I feel him melting. I place my arm around his shoulder, as the sunlight shines on his cheek. The balconies of the Capulet mansion look down on us and the green gardens. Tybalt lowers his gaze slowly, his tension unwinding. ‚ÄúHow,‚Äù he asks me, ‚Äúdo you forgive?‚Äù I‚Äôm not sure how to answer. I look down at the terra cotta. ‚ÄùMaybe it‚Äôs about letting go,‚Äù I say, ‚Äúeven when you‚Äôve been wronged.‚Äù But I‚Äôm not satisfied with my answer. A starling flies over our heads. I look up, watching it, and say the first thing that comes to mind. ‚ÄúI lied to Orion‚Äî‚Äù I explain, as an example. ‚ÄúBut he forgave me.‚Äù Tybalt freezes in my arms. Oh‚Äîwhy did I mention Ori? All his gentleness is gone. I feel his hard exterior reforming. How stupid could I be? Tybalt stands abruptly, backing away from me. I was only trying to share with him. His eyes blaze a sad hate. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù says Tybalt. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt forgive you.‚Äù He is stepping backward, retreating into the shadow of the Capulet mansion. Already the Verona sun is disappearing behind the clouds. The stone mansion is crumbling, stone by stone. In its place, the glass Capulet lab returns like a prison. Above the skylight is the swirling, black storm. I‚Äôm still holding out my hand, stunned. Tybalt retreats from me, returning to the grey shadow of Tai, in the Capulet lab. He stares hatefully into Tai‚Äôs face, then steps inside him. My brother is gone. Now Tai is glaring at me. The glass Capulet lab is as sterile as ever. I‚Äôm no longer covered in beautiful lace, but back in my hoodie. The retrieval is over. Tai stares at me with demented hate. For the first time, I feel in danger. The black storm has arrived. Above the skylight, the clouds are dark with rain. I can‚Äôt tell if the darkness is the storm or the time of day. How long have we been in retrieval? Have I missed The Lights? ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, Zu,‚Äù Tai‚Äôs voice is hollow. ‚ÄúThis time, I can‚Äôt let you leave.‚Äù The storm clouds are swirling violently above the skylight. I back out of the lab. Descending the stairs, I see a store filled with busy shoppers. Beyond the glass walls is the storm. I walk calmly toward the exit. Two Capulet guards come for me. I quicken my step, but one of them grabs my arm. I can‚Äôt break free. The glass doorway is just steps ahead. From my periphery, I see some shoppers around me, beginning to run. Suddenly the glass wall of the Capulet store shatters. Glass shards fly overhead. Everyone around me dives to the floor. I hear the crunching, cracking sound of a hundred things breaking. The Nepenthe tables are somersaulting through the air, sideswiped by a white car drifting across the showroom floor. I crouch down, shielding my face. The white car slides to a stop, as the passenger door opens. ‚ÄúCome on, honey,‚Äù I see Lauren‚Äôs face. The Capulet guards are distracted just enough. I fling myself into her car.

Title: ZU √ó ORI Creator: Sov Logline: NYC high-schoolers Zu and Ori discover the trauma, drama, and karma of their past lives as Juliet and Romeo, defying a prophecy that threatens to repeat their tragic past.

Primary Location: New York City (Trinity Rose High School, Central Park, various city locations) Secondary Locations: Verona, Italy & Revolutionary France (flashbacks to past lives and historical events)

Age: 16 Birthplace: Hong Kong School: Trinity Rose, NYC Backstory: Recently moved from Hong Kong. Scene 12.1 Lucrezia‚Äã My first memory is fuzzy, warm. I can‚Äôt even see the people around me, but I can feel them. I can feel their love. They appear as soft colored shapes around me, loving me. I close my eyes. In a state of half sleep, I can hear their gauzy voices, reverberating around me. I let go into the sound. I feel safe. Scene 12.2 Lucrezia‚Äã My next memory. I‚Äôm with my mother. We‚Äôre outdoors in a grassy place. I am old enough to stand. There‚Äôs a breeze in the trees and in the grass. My mother is wearing black. But I can‚Äôt see her face. I reach for her hand. There are others nearby. They act solemn and also dress in black. My mother stands in front of the grave. Her head is bowed, I can‚Äôt see her face. ‚ÄúSay goodbye, Lucrezia.‚Äù I say goodbye. I hold her hand. We turn away. Scene 12.3 Lucrezia‚Äã I watch a video with my mother. I am seven or eight years old. On the screen is my father, arms out, encouraging me, while I crawl forward. I have no memory of this. I was too young. I watch closely, studying my father‚Äôs features and his movements. I want to learn more, about who he was. I wish the video was better quality. I want to see my father‚Äôs face more clearly. But I can see him, smiling. As I crawl toward him. I glance sideways at my mother, hoping she‚Äôll say something. But she‚Äôs absorbed in the screen. She doesn‚Äôt notice me watching. I go into my bedroom. On my desk is a small picture of my father. I sit forward in my chair. I pull the picture close. Scene 12.4 Lucrezia‚Äã I became a good student. I felt a certain pleasure at arriving at definite answers. Naturally, my science classes became my favorite. Chemistry in particular. At the university, I make it my focus. In addition to balancing equations, I enjoy being in the lab, in my white coat and goggles. I keep mainly to myself, but I feel a strange new sensation. Belonging, I guess. I make some friends. We hang out together, in the evening city after classes, going from one place to another. I am learning to feel comfortable with others. We sit at a caf√©. A car pulls up along the curb. It‚Äôs the father of one of my friends. I watch as he steps out, as she hugs her father warmly. It‚Äôs a warmth I‚Äôve never experienced. We are offered a ride. I decline, politely. The others go on without me. I walk onward, up the evening street alone. I return to the fuzzy warm memory, when I was a baby. That‚Äôs all I have. Scene 12.5 Lucrezia‚Äã Later I see a posting on my phone. It‚Äôs something liked by my chemistry department. Are you interested in memory? Do you wish you remembered more? Would you like to help others remember? APPLY HERE I click, filling out a form. A month passes. I receive a message from the head of the chemistry department. He reveals that the application is for an unnamed perfume company. And I am accepted! I attend an accelerated program at a respected perfume school, during the next summers. I don‚Äôt consider myself especially gifted with scent, but I am a hard worker. And I want to remember. Only when I graduate do I learn the perfume company is the famous House of Capulet. I am invited to Verona. My task is to make memories. I accept. Scene 12.6 Lucrezia‚Äã I am not told much, at first. Only that I am to work on a very important and historical fragrance. One of the earliest Capulet perfumes, which has always had imperfections. But which may help people remember. I support this. I am given a diluted version of the perfume. It comes in a red bottle. Working late in the lab, I frequently sense something unusual. About the silent Verona night. Like a friendly, familiar touch. I enjoy these nights, maybe because I am alone in the lab. I stare into the deep red liquid, on the table before me. I begin my work. As usual, I experience the awakening of memory from the scent of the perfume. But instead of a single memory, the red fragrance seems to evoke many. From my early life and from my childhood. I become curious. How far back will it take me? I test variations, noting the differences. Secretly, I am hoping for another memory. Of my father. But it never comes. I‚Äôm always led back to the one. To the warm, fuzzy memory. Which I know so well. I have been in the lab all night, growing tired. I‚Äôve been entrusted with a stronger version of the red perfume. I reach for another oil. My coat sleeve sweeps the bottle. The red liquid spills out onto the table. At first, I‚Äôm shocked. I smell the pure, earthy fragrance. Immediately I‚Äôm brought back to that first, blurry memory. That warm, fuzzy memory. My favorite memory. My only memory. Of my father. But it doesn‚Äôt stop here. I‚Äôm remembering more. There is more, before this memory. There are other memories, behind this memory. I feel my skin tingling, awake. This isn‚Äôt my first memory of my father. There are others. Many others. Before this. Now I remember. I am walking to meet him. I don‚Äôt know where I am. I don‚Äôt know when. Only before. I am going to him, with others beside me. We travel down the long pathway. We enter into the sanctuary. He stands alone, his back to me. He is not my father, not yet. But he will be. The others leave us alone. It‚Äôs only the two of us, in the high stone room. This isn‚Äôt the first time we‚Äôve met. We have stood here together, many times. I am watching the back of his robe. Filled with adoration. This is a special moment. The moment I‚Äôve been waiting for. Then. And now. My whole life. He is turning around, to face me. As the memory blacks out. Scene 12.7 Lucrezia‚Äã I can see no more. Night after night I return there. To the sanctuary, to the man with his back to me. But I go no further. The door to this memory is locked. I don‚Äôt have the key. Honestly, I barely knew what this was. What was I seeing? But I couldn‚Äôt look at anything the same again. I finally confide in Tai. ‚ÄúWhat am I remembering?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your past life, Lu,‚Äù Tai answers, distractedly. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the whole point of the red perfume.‚Äù It‚Äôs different, having it spelled out. ‚ÄúHow do I see more?‚Äù But Tai just laughs at me, shaking his head. ‚ÄúBe careful what you wish for.‚Äù So I return alone, in my memory. Again and again. But the memory always ends. Before I see his face. But I have to know. Could I go on, without knowing? Everything depends on this. But no matter what I try, I can never go further. I can never go past this moment. Of standing behind this person. Who would be my father. And waiting for him. To face me. Scene 12.8 Zu‚Äã We reverse out the Capulet store. A slab of glass shatters over the windshield. One of the Capulet guards paws on the window. His hands thump harmlessly on the glass. I see Tai, at the top of the stairs. For a moment, our eyes meet. I‚Äôve never seen such pain. Then he‚Äôs left behind. We‚Äôre accelerating up the New York streets. Behind us is the Capulet store. Above us, the black storm. ‚ÄúLauren‚Äî‚Äú I say. ‚ÄúI told you‚Äî‚Äù she turns, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd look out for you.‚Äù The brown buildings are speeding by. I‚Äôm breathing on pure adrenaline. I can see the black storm clouds swirling. Newspapers and plastic bags are blowing over the street and sidewalks. It‚Äôs exactly like my vision. ‚ÄúWhat time is it?‚Äù I ask suddenly. ‚ÄúYou missed your slot,‚Äù says Lauren. ‚ÄúBut we might still make it.‚Äù I go into free fall. Has it really been that long? Everything is happening at full speed. My thoughts, the storm and the streets are racing. The past sixty seconds feels like ten. ‚ÄúUh oh‚Äî‚Äú Lauren snaps her head back. Two small black cars are closing in fast. Their small size is allowing them to weave through the crowded lanes. From the look of them, they are Italian. Of course. Scene 12.9 Tai‚Äã I watch the shattered Capulet store. It hardly seems to matter anymore. I return inside to the perfume lab. I feel a gripping pain in my heart, like a blistering flame. It‚Äôs the pain I always feel. But I can‚Äôt ignore it anymore. I ask myself: Where did this pain come from? Why do I feel this? I need to know. It was already there, in Verona. Lucrezia bursts through the doors. ‚ÄúWhere have you been?‚Äù she shouts, alarmed. ‚ÄúHave you seen‚Äî‚Äù ‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù I turn away. My right hand is locked in a ball. ‚ÄúDid you see Zu?‚Äù ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs gone.‚Äù ‚ÄúGone?‚Äù I continue into the lab. Lucrezia follows after me, anxiously. ‚ÄúBut you said‚Äî‚Äú she stammers, ‚ÄúZu was going to help us!‚Äù ‚ÄúI was wrong.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut the red perfume,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúOur memory work.‚Äù I‚Äôm no longer interested. I‚Äôve never cared about the memory perfume, anyway. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt bring back your father, Lu. It‚Äôs too late.‚Äù ‚ÄúMaybe for you,‚Äù she replies. She turns toward the frosted doors of the lab. ‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe theater,‚Äù she says brusquely. Lucrezia rushes out of the perfume lab. The doors close behind her. I continue, toward the ceramic table in the center of the lab. Ahead of me, RITA is waiting. Scene 12.10 Zu‚Äã A black motorcycle speeds up behind the two Capulet cars, joining them. Lauren accelerates, in response. We‚Äôre racing up between the tall brown buildings. The rolling storm clouds are pitch black, which chills me more than the pursuing Capulets. It‚Äôs mid afternoon in New York, but it looks like night. The black cars are right behind us. One of them pulls alongside. I can see the Capulet driver, in his finely pressed shirt. Seeing him, I realize: the Capulets aren‚Äôt evil. They‚Äôre just stuck in the past. Trying to control others. They haven't evolved past that stage. The Capulet driver veers his car directly into us, grinding the metal of our cars together. Trying to force us off the road. So I don‚Äôt get to The Lights. So I don‚Äôt make my appointment. So I don‚Äôt escape them. His car window rolls down. The driver strikes my window with a heavy baton, once and twice. But it doesn‚Äôt break the glass. Lauren looks at me, impressed. The next blow shatters glass all over me. The Capulet driver leaps into my window, his car veering astray without him, careening into parked cars. He‚Äôs reaching for the steering wheel. I‚Äôm grappling with Capulet driver, as he dangles from the window. His legs narrowly miss the passing cars. We swerve from one lane to another. Behind us, the second black car slams into us, trying to unbalance us. Ahead the yellow light turns red. Lauren accelerates through it. Cars from both directions scream by us. I grab the Capulet driver by the collar, with both my hands. Our eyes lock deeply, inches apart. Something is happening. His face begins to change. I‚Äôm seeing one face after another, layered over his physical features. A teenage boy, then a beautiful young girl, then an older woman gaze back at me. It‚Äôs a multi-life time crossing. Somehow I‚Äôve triggered it. A half dozen of the Capulet driver‚Äôs past lives appear before me. Each one is searching me. Eye to eye. I‚Äôve never experienced anything like this. I didn‚Äôt even know it was possible. I am seeing thousands of years of their past. What I‚Äôm seeing is the real Capulet driver. Who doesn‚Äôt want to hurt me. Who‚Äôs only joined the Capulets in this life, anyway. Who doesn‚Äôt care about this chase. We are connecting, human to human. We speed onward for a block, like this. Eye to eye. The Capulet driver has stopped fighting. He‚Äôs too immersed in what he‚Äôs seeing about his past. He holds my gaze, intently. Then he simply lets go. His body drops away from Lauren‚Äôs car. I look back, watching him rolling over the pavement. Beside me, Lauren meets my gaze. She‚Äôs seen what just happened. The other Capulet car and motorcycle are swerving behind us, darting through traffic. All three vehicles race onward. Under the darkening storm. Scene 12.11 Ori‚Äã I‚Äôm backstage with Hermes. I haven't heard from Zu all day. The final performances are concluding. A girl in VR goggles is throwing daggers at a boy strapped to a spinning wheel. I turn away from the stage. ‚ÄúWhere is she?‚Äù I glare at Hermes. Hermes evades my gaze. ‚ÄúWhat happens if we miss the appointment?‚Äù I ask. Hermes steps away. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want to find out,‚Äù he says. I stare at Hermes, anxiously. The VR girl is coming offstage to applause, carrying her batch of daggers. She removes her headset, her hair spilling free as she passes me. ‚ÄúCan I borrow that?‚Äù I point to a dagger. In our rush, we‚Äôve completely forgotten our props. ‚ÄúSure.‚Äù She hands me the dagger. ‚ÄúBe careful, it‚Äôs sharp.‚Äù I nod, distantly. Aisha hurries up to me. ‚ÄúOri, I looked everywhere,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThis is the best I could find.‚Äù She pulls out a green glass vial. It‚Äôs Nepenthe. ‚ÄúWhere did you get that?‚Äù I recoil. ‚ÄúUmm, I bought it?‚Äù Aisha answers, guiltily. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt tried it yet. Maybe it‚Äôll work?‚Äù I hate the absolute sight of it. But it‚Äôs also perfect. For our performance. ‚ÄúThanks, Aisha,‚Äù I take the vial. Hermes is watching me. Scene 12.12 Hermes‚Äã I come up on the rooftop. It‚Äôs the night before The Lights. In the moonlight, Ori and Zu are sitting on the ledge, casually looking out over the city. ‚ÄúWell, my holograms are done,‚Äù I say. They look pleased. I jump on the ledge beside them. But I sense something. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre discussing the weather,‚Äù Zu tells me. The skies are clear above the city lights. ‚ÄúFor tomorrow.‚Äù I look toward Zu. ‚ÄúWhen I first met Tai,‚Äù Zu explains, ‚Äúhe gave me Orpheus, a perfume that shows the future. I saw a brick mansion and a black storm, and Ori lying dead in a circle. That brick mansion was your home, Hermes. It was the future.‚Äù Ori looks out at the city. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs only one of three,‚Äù Ori points out. ‚ÄúOnly one of the three has happened!‚Äù ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that enough?‚Äù asks Zu. ‚ÄúAnd if there‚Äôs a storm tomorrow? That will be two of three.‚Äù I gaze at Zu and Ori‚Äôs faces. ‚ÄúWhat are you suggesting?‚Äù Orion asks. ‚ÄúWe skip The Lights?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know!‚Äù Ori stands up on the ledge. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt protect me,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs our future, that‚Äôs our future. That‚Äôs our destiny.‚Äù Zu stands up also. ‚ÄúI can do The Lights‚Äîwithout you.‚Äù Orion walks away, shaking his head. ‚ÄúYou said it yourself. It‚Äôs what we do together." Zu sighs, audibly. ‚ÄúHermes?‚Äù she looks at me. ‚ÄúYou met for a reason,‚Äù I say simply. ‚ÄúLove can change the world. When you give it everything‚Äîeven when you don‚Äôt know why or what happens next.‚Äù I look at them. ‚ÄúThen love becomes a gift.‚Äù The three of us look out across the city. The moon and stars shine down upon the buildings. Scene 12.13 Zu‚Äã The second Capulet car slams us from behind. Alongside us, the third Capulet races up on the black motorcycle. I see her blazing red hair, rippling in the wind. She leaps out onto the glass roof of Lauren‚Äôs car, shattering it instantly and landing on top of me. The red-haired Capulet seizes me. But immediately the same thing happens. Our eyes meet, I am seeing into her past. A series of ghostly faces appears, one after another. It‚Äôs impossible for her to keep fighting me. Something is changing. She looks as if she‚Äôs always known me. As if we‚Äôve been friends. Now there‚Äôs a blue light above us. It‚Äôs the blue light from my dream of Verona. And the Capulet lab. But what‚Äôs it doing here? Scene 12.14 Tai‚Äã ‚ÄúRough day, Tai?‚Äù says RITA. ‚ÄúI need to see something,‚Äù I say. RITA wavers in red. ‚ÄúYou mean, remember something?‚Äù she asks me. I stand before the ceramic altar-like table, gripping the surface. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúTai,‚Äù says RITA, ‚ÄúI never agreed with your uncle giving you the memory trial. You weren‚Äôt ready.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat was left out?‚Äù I demand. ‚ÄúAll your lives before Verona.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù ‚ÄúThey weren‚Äôt necessary.‚Äù ‚ÄúI need to see them.‚Äù I place my left palm on the table. From below the surface, a beam of light scans my hand. A red vial begins rising from the interior of the table. ‚ÄúI warn you,‚Äù says RITA, ‚Äúthis is extremely risky.‚Äù The red vial comes to a stop. It stands atop a bright red square on the tabletop. On the side of the vial is a digital reading. It reads: 10% I move my finger upward along the vial, sliding the reading to 100%. ‚ÄúTai, this potency will allow you to remember all your past lives,‚Äù RITA announces. ‚ÄúI know.‚Äù ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt allow it,‚Äù RITA is silent a moment. ‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt be able to handle the integration. In the blue light of the tomb, I reach out to him. I can feel him here, behind his frozen shape. I reach out to him. To bring him back. In this blue light and us That‚Äôs all that exists Now and forever We will be I can feel him. Behind his eyes. Reaching out to me. To bring him back. My tears fall over his face. I kiss his lips. Until I feel his eyes. Meeting mine. Beside him, his Verona hologram remains lifeless, lying on the stage. Scene 12.34 Hermes‚Äã I leave my place, off-stage. I make my way, around the outside hallway. Toward the front entrance of the theater. Approaching the entrance is Tai. I block his path. We stand there, several steps apart. ‚ÄúI need to go in,‚Äù says Tai. ‚ÄúNo way,‚Äù I reply. We both know who we are. We‚Äôve stood this way before. On that final day in Verona. With our swords drawn high. I remember it well, like yesterday. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt understand‚Äî‚Äú Tai steps forward. ‚ÄúStop,‚Äú I say. ‚ÄúMercutio‚Äî‚Äú ‚ÄúMy name is Hermes.‚Äù Tai appears strained, soaking wet. ‚ÄúVerona,‚Äù he says rapidly, ‚Äúwas a long time ago.‚Äù ‚ÄúNot that long,‚Äù I say. I have forgotten nothing. From the last time we met. Standing face to face, just like now. But a different place, a different face. This villain, his sword in my side. ‚ÄúSwallow your pride‚Äî‚Äù Tai says to me. ‚ÄúThis is more important than you. Or me.‚Äù I rest my eye on Tai. I am remembering that day in Verona. Remembering my rage. Remembering my pain. From that day. ‚ÄúGet out of my way,‚Äù says Tai. I stare into his eyes. Scene 12.35 Zu‚Äã Ori‚Äôs eyes are like the sky. I feel his eyes on mine. Coming back to me. Coming back from Nepenthe. Our heads are pressed together. We sit there together, supporting each other. I have my arm around him. Together we stand. Our backs to the audience. We are walking away. Toward the back of the stage. Only the holograms. Remain. Scene 12.36 Lucrezia‚Äã Everyone has left their seats. There‚Äôs a buzz around the theater. People are milling about, discussing what they have seen. I remain where I sit, unmoving. The photo of my father stares up at me. I feel something trapped in my heart. I sit staring at my phone. It‚Äôs a lifetime of loss. Lodged in my heart. I don‚Äôt have thoughts. Only loss. And longing. I rise, moving forward. Toward the stage. I pass through the evening guests. People are passing on my left and right, but no one notices me. I climb the stairs to the stage. And no one notices me. Ahead of me stands the dagger. Still stuck in the stage. I step toward it. I pick it up. Scene 12.37 Tai‚Äã I step toward Hermes. Passing him, as in slow motion. Eye to eye. Hermes watches me, allowing me to pass. I open the theater doors. The performance has ended and people are moving all about. I‚Äôm looking urgently around for Orion. I push my way through the crowd. Toward the stage. Scene 12.38 Zu‚Äã Backstage it‚Äôs strangely silent. No one is speaking. But they are gathering around us. Everyone has something to say. I can see it, in their faces. Something special has happened. But no one can say what it is. Kimmo comes up to me. ‚ÄúOh my goodness,‚Äù she holds out her phone. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs blowing up.‚Äù I see a video of us on stage. I am leaning over Ori‚Äôs body, my eyes wet. I am kissing him. It‚Äôs already at 1.2M views. People are in the comments, crying. Talking about it. 1.5M views. I hold Ori‚Äôs hand. ‚ÄúOrion‚Äî‚Äú Behind us, it‚Äôs Lauren. I see Ori smile. Scene 12.39 Lucrezia‚Äã I move backstage. There are people everywhere. I can‚Äôt feel anything. I am only thinking of my father. My eyes are directly ahead. I hold the dagger against my leg. What I am doing? I don‚Äôt know. Everything is upside down. Inside my heart. All I know. Is I have to see my father again. And I need Zu‚Äôs help. To see my father again. No one notices me. I move forward. Unfeeling. Toward Orion. Scene 12.40 Lauren‚Äã ‚ÄúLauren‚Äî‚Äú he smiles at me. I look at Orion and Zu. There‚Äôs a throng around them. They stand together in the middle of the circle. Ori‚Äôs eyes are starry. His expression is open. At peace. Scene 12.41 Lucrezia‚Äã I thrust the dagger deep. It hardly feels like me. I feel the blade press into the flesh. I feel the body slump forward against me. I step backward, shaken, my power gone. The dagger falls from my hands, clattering onto the floor. But something has happened. Scene 12.42 Lucrezia‚Äã I am back with my father. It‚Äôs the place I‚Äôve been a dozen times. The memory I‚Äôve had a dozen times. Standing behind him. Alone in the high stone room. I‚Äôve just thrust my fist at him. It‚Äôs the same motion, the same emotion as the dagger. That‚Äôs what triggered the memory. I am angry at my father, because he‚Äôs telling me I have to go away. Because I‚Äôm being sent away. So I‚Äôve struck at him with my fist. Now he turns to meet me. The point where my memory always blacks out. But not this time. Now I see his face. Now I see his face. He is smiling at me. There is so much love in his face. So much love for me. The love I have missed. My whole life. And now I am crying. ‚ÄúI am sorry,‚Äù he says deeply. I wait, breathless. ‚ÄúI had to leave you,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAs a baby. I stayed with you as long as I could.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I ask in tears. ‚ÄúIt was the only way you would find me,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI had to give you the motivation to find me.‚Äù I look at him in wonder. ‚ÄúAnd here you are,‚Äù he smiles. He holds my hand, the hand I've hit him with. His eyes are clear, like the stars. ‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôm about to show you,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúwill change the future of the world. But afterward, you must forget everything you have seen.‚Äù He looks through my eyes. ‚ÄúFor many, many lifetimes,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAnything,‚Äù I trust him, completely. In the stone room, the blue light is descending. The blue light we both know so well. ‚ÄúYou will go lifetimes,‚Äú he warns me, ‚Äúwithout me. You will feel alone and abandoned. You will feel your friends are far away. You will have to go places you don‚Äôt want to go. You will have to do things you don‚Äôt want to do. But you can never lose faith. And we will meet again.‚Äù He leans forward. He is speaking to me. But his words appear as shapes in my mind. I hear his words as shapes in my mind. The shapes tell the story of the world. The secret history of the world. I watch clear-eyed. ‚ÄúThese secrets will be safe,‚Äù says my father. ‚ÄúThey will be hidden even from you, within your forgotten memory. Until one day,‚Äù he smiles. ‚ÄúUntil one day, you remember them again." Scene 12.43 Tai‚Äã I feel the blade in my side. I feel Lucrezia‚Äôs hand, her warmth against me. I smell the sweet lilac fragrance of her. That I have come to know so well. And never appreciated. I slump to the floor. At her feet. Scene 12.44 Zu‚Äã Tai lies bleeding. He rushed toward Orion and threw himself against Lucrezia. She stands over him, in a trance. The red dagger drops from her hand. She stares at her hands, unbelieving. I drop beside Tai, my hand on his chest. He stares upward at me. ‚ÄúForgive me, Zu‚Äî‚Äú I grab his hand in mine. ‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù ‚ÄúMy life,‚Äú he stares upward. ‚ÄúAnd the one before.‚Äù ‚ÄúI was filled with pain,‚Äù Tai tries to breathe. ‚ÄúAnd hate. When all I wanted was love.‚Äù His face is pale. ‚ÄúYou were always loved,‚Äù I say. Tai closes his eyes. ‚ÄúNow I can see,‚Äù he coughs, his body shaking. Lucrezia is beside me. She stares forward, otherworldly. ‚ÄúOrion‚Äî‚Äú Tai calls out. Ori is kneeling beside him, opposite me. Tai lifts his hand weakly. Ori takes it firmly. ‚ÄúForgive me,‚Äù says Tai, "for what I‚Äôve done.‚Äù ‚ÄúI forgive you,‚Äù Orion says deeply. He holds Tai‚Äôs hand within his grasp. I look at Ori through tears. Lucrezia is kneeling over him. She appears as if in two worlds at once. ‚ÄúTai, Tai‚Äî‚Äú she is crying. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm so sorry. Please don‚Äôt go, I‚Äôm sorry‚Äî‚Äù Tai lifts his eyes. ‚ÄúThis is what I wanted,‚Äù his lips smile. Lucrezia grasps Tai‚Äôs hand, as tightly as she can. She looks at him, holding his gaze, as intently and lovingly as she can. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll see you again,‚Äù he says. Tai lies lengthwise on the floor. I bend over him, my hand touching his heart. Lucrezia is draped across Tai‚Äôs chest. Ori and I each hold one of his hands. Standing around us are Hermes and Lauren, who wipes her eyes. Kimmo and Aisha and all the others surround us, motionless. Their eyes where Tai is lying. The room is absolutely still. The floor is white except for Tai‚Äôs blood. Above, it rains down on the skylight. Tai lies dead inside our circle.

At Trinity Rose High School, newcomer ZU struggles with the enigmatic sketches she has drawn, feeling a strange connection to them without knowing why. Her encounter with ORI, a gifted but mysterious student, unlocks a flood of past-life memories from their time in Verona. This revelation also impacts their teacher, PROFESSOR LAUREN, and Ori‚Äôs best friend, HERMES, each carrying wounds from their own Verona lives. As Zu and Ori unravel their pasts as Juliet and Romeo, they uncover a vast world of reincarnation, time crossings, hidden mysteries, and an ancient destiny stretching across centuries‚Äîone that divides those who remember their past lives from those who do not. As they piece together their tragedy in Verona, they realize why fate has drawn them together once more. Their reunion is threatened when the bitter TAI, the reincarnated Tybalt Capulet, confronts Zu with a terrible prophecy: unless she returns to the Capulets, history will repeat itself, and Ori will die once again. Tai gives her Nepenthe, a powerful perfume that erases past-life memories, forcing her to choose between preserving Ori's memories and saving his life. As the weight of the past tests Zu and Ori's evolving relationship, Ori proposes they collaborate for Trinity Rose‚Äôs annual performance event, The Lights. But destiny takes a dark turn when Zu accidentally inhales Nepenthe, wiping her memories of Verona. To save their future, Ori braves the painful Montague retrieval process (guided by Hermes), awakening powerful forces from his past life as Romeo. With the threat of Nepenthe and humanity‚Äôs future at stake, Zu and Ori's performance at The Lights becomes a stage‚Äîwhere every character must either succumb to their painful past or break free to fulfill their destiny.

This guide unravels the deep lore of ZU √ó ORI, mapping the cycles of reincarnation, the forces driving fate, and the secrets buried in Verona‚Äôs past. It provides a clear reference for understanding the myths, prophecies, and rivalries that shape Zu and Ori‚Äôs journey across lifetimes.

The Montagues and Capulets trace their animosity back to medieval Verona, Italy. Once allied houses in trade and influence, their conflict deepened over something far greater‚Äîthe power of memory itself. Shakespeare‚Äôs Romeo and Juliet gives little detail about the origins of the feud‚Äîonly that it was ancient, bitter, and unresolved. Yet its history runs far deeper. For generations, the Capulets were master perfumers, pioneering fragrances not just for pleasure but for unlocking fragments of memory, including past lives. Their secret art of perfumery, passed down through generations, produced fragrances capable of unlocking memories buried across lifetimes‚Äîa power the Capulets carefully guarded and refined. They believed that controlling memory meant controlling destiny, shaping the future by learning from the past. Juliet was born into this world, raised among potions that unlocked deeper truths‚Äîyet she died before playing a part in the Capulet legacy. The Montagues, by contrast, followed a different path, one rooted in philosophy, mysticism, and inner knowledge. They saw past lives not as something to be engineered but as an unfolding journey of karma‚Äîone that could not be manipulated without consequence. Their leaders were known as Montague Initiates, a lineage of scholars, warriors, and seekers dedicated to breaking the cycle of predetermined fate. They opposed the Capulets‚Äô growing monopoly on memory, fearing that such power, if misused, could trap souls in a dangerous loop rather than liberate them. Romeo and Juliet‚Äôs deaths did not end the families' feud‚Äîbut it was a turning point. Faced with the loss of Juliet‚Äôs unique gift of scent, the Capulets abandoned their efforts to perfect their memory perfumes. Instead, they turned to a prophecy‚Äîbelieving that one day, Juliet would reincarnate to complete their work. The rivalry continued to simmer, largely underground, spanning centuries. The Capulets awaited Juliet‚Äôs return, convinced she would one day help them perfect "the red perfume" and unlock the full power of past-life memory. For their part, the Montagues developed their own techniques of past-life retrieval‚Äîa safer, more gradual method, guiding individuals toward remembrance rather than forcing it through artificial means.

Once a strict family lineage, the Montagues have evolved into a hidden, enlightened society dedicated to spiritual awakening and emotional freedom. Their purpose is helping others remember past lives, breaking karmic cycles and healing historic traumas. Key Figures: Hermes Wright (Reincarnation of Mercutio) ‚Äì A brilliant, tech-savvy visionary and Montague guide. Santiaga (Reincarnation of Tabithe) ‚Äì A powerful Montague leader, previously an Initiate in 18th-century France. Ori (Reincarnation of Romeo) ‚Äì A hero of our present story, with a destiny of his own. The Blue Light ‚Äì A mysterious, otherworldly force connected to Montague Initiates.

During the French Revolution, Mercutio reincarnates as Delphine, who is mentored by Tabithe (later reincarnated as Santiaga). This era highlights the Montagues' continuous struggle for truth, freedom, and justice, even amidst social upheaval. Tabithe and Delphine‚Äôs adventures in Revolutionary France comprise an entire volume of the Montague lore.

Today, the Montagues operate discreetly, focusing on awakening individuals to their pasts to achieve personal liberation. With Santiaga (Tabithe) as a key leader, Hermes as a guide, and Orion awakened to his true identity, the Montagues are once again entwined with the reincarnation of Juliet‚Äîand the battle for the future of memory itself.

Originating in Verona, the Capulets developed a powerful legacy rooted in perfumery, alchemy, and emotional control. Throughout history, their perfumes became renowned for their potent ability to manipulate memories and emotions, evolving from medieval alchemical practices into modern biochemical expertise. Key Figures: Tai Fang (Tybalt Capulet reincarnate) ‚Äì Juliet‚Äôs once-devoted brother and creator of Nepenthe. Lucrezia de Rosa ‚Äì A gifted Capulet scientist devoted to unlocking the past through scent. RITA ‚Äì An advanced AI assisting in the development of Capulet perfumes. Fang An ‚Äì Chairman of Zhu Perfume and owner of the House of Capulet.

Since the Middle Ages, the Capulets have utilized alchemical and perfumery skills to create potent fragrances affecting memory and emotions. Their most infamous perfumes: The Red Perfume (M): Enables vivid recall of past-life experiences. Orpheus: Enables visions of potential futures. Nepenthe: Blocks painful memories, promoting emotional oblivion.

The House of Capulet uses Nepenthe to suppress emotions and erase past-life memories, ensuring that individuals remain disconnected from their history and easier to manipulate. By promoting forgetting as a solution to suffering, they control collective memory, reshape personal identities, and erase inconvenient truths.

A 500-year-old prophecy foretells that Juliet‚Äôs reincarnation (Zu)‚Äîwith her extraordinary sense of smell, is the key to perfecting the Capulet's long-sought past-life memory perfume ‚ÄúM‚Äù (the Red Perfume). Aided by Zu‚Äôs unique gifts, this breakthrough could revolutionize humanity‚Äôs understanding of memory and identity forever. But there‚Äôs a danger. With the perfume‚Äôs power solely under Capulet control, it risks being manipulated for their own ends, shaping the course of history in ways that could be both profound and perilous.

Zu and Ori remain the heart of this expansive saga. Zu's tragic death (as Juliet) halted the Capulets' pursuit of the perfect memory perfume, and now her return reignites their quest to complete it. As Romeo and Juliet, their love changed the world‚Äîand by choosing love over life itself, they set the tone for the modern love story. Now, their journey is about more than memory; it‚Äôs about the future of love. The only ones who awaken to their past purely through the power of their own connection, Zu and Ori follow where love leads them‚Äîand take the world with them.
documents.s: ZU √ó ORI: The Return of Romeo and Juliet ‚ù§Ô∏èüî•

documents.t: This section delves into the mystical core of ZU √ó ORI, exploring the intricate processes of reincarnation, the unique ways memories traverse lifetimes, and the profound mechanisms‚Äîsuch as Time Crossings and Appointments‚Äîthat bind characters across past, present, and future. Understanding these phenomena is vital for grasping the powerful emotional and narrative dynamics at play in the ZU √ó ORI universe.

Time crossings are rare occurrences where characters simultaneously experience past-life events alongside their current existence. Triggered by intense emotional experiences, these crossings unlock deep memories, influencing present actions and relationships. In ZU √ó ORI, Zu experiences a vivid time crossing after a car accident, recalling her past life as Juliet. Similarly, when fleeing an argument with Zu, Ori finds himself reliving his banishment from Verona along the Mantua road, vividly recalling his tragic past as Romeo.

Retrieval refers to the Montague practice of intentionally accessing past-life memories, often facilitated by guides or mentors. It involves emotionally intense and sometimes painful experiences, designed to break karmic cycles and heal unresolved traumas. For instance, Hermes guides Ori through a difficult retrieval process (in E9 Timelines), allowing Ori to relive a confrontation with Tybalt and unlock powerful aspects of himself.

Familiarity describes the deep, subconscious recognition between reincarnated souls. It manifests as an immediate connection, profound understanding, or intense emotional response without logical explanation, signaling significant past-life bonds. Many of the characters in ZU √ó ORI experience this phenomenon, much as we all do occasionally in our own lives.

Appointments are pre-arranged, destined meetings. They occur at precise moments, locations, or under specific conditions, and are pivotal in guiding characters toward their ultimate destinies. Missed appointments can abruptly alter one's fate. One of the most significant appointments in ZU √ó ORI is Zu and Ori's performance at The Lights, a crucial event weaving together the destinies of all characters.

Timelines are the paths shaped by our choices and key meetings (appointments) throughout one life or across many lifetimes. They show how choices, big and small, move us closer or further from our ultimate destinies. Characters in ZU √ó ORI navigate their timelines by trusting their intuition, following their inner truths, or with guidance from mystical sources like the Blue Light. These timelines span thousands of years, linking Zu and Ori's lifetimes‚Äîincluding their significant past as Juliet and Romeo.

Reincarnation is a widespread belief appearing prominently in various cultures and religions, including Hinduism, Buddhism, and ancient Greek philosophy. Many ancient cultures saw reincarnation as a meaningful journey, where souls continually evolve toward wisdom and enlightenment through multiple lifetimes. Greek philosophers like Plato and Pythagoras taught that reincarnation was a path toward moral growth and spiritual perfection. However, the belief in reincarnation faced significant challenges over time. In 553 CE, Emperor Justinian of the Roman Empire banned teachings related to reincarnation at the Second Council of Constantinople, seeing it as a threat to his political and religious authority. His actions significantly suppressed reincarnation beliefs in Western culture, shaping how people perceived life and death for centuries afterward. This historical context provides a deeper understanding of the challenges faced by characters in ZU √ó ORI as they navigate memories and identities rooted in suppressed beliefs. This guide supports consistency, creativity, and deep narrative understanding for all collaborators. üå†

This document provides a comprehensive look at the worldbuilding of ZU √ó ORI, exploring the characters, settings, cultures, organizations, and supernatural elements that shape the universe of the story.

ZU √ó ORI is an epic reincarnation tale that weaves together the past and present, centering on NYC high-schoolers Zu and Ori, who discover they are the reborn Juliet Capulet and Romeo Montague. Their love story spans across centuries, haunted by fate, memory, and a prophecy that threatens to repeat their tragic past. üåÄüíî

Zu (Agnes Zhu) ‚Äì 16, an artist with hyperosmia (superhuman sense of smell), drawn to Ori by an unexplainable force. (Past Life: Juliet Capulet) Ori (Orion Moore) ‚Äì 17, a gifted costume designer, haunted by past-life trauma. (Past Life: Romeo Montague) Hermes Wright ‚Äì Ori‚Äôs best friend, tech prodigy, and reincarnated Mercutio, with memories of a second past life as Delphine in Revolutionary France. Professor Lauren ‚Äì Theater history teacher at Trinity Rose and unaware reincarnation of Friar Lawrence. Santiaga ‚Äì A leader within the Montague Initiates, with a special connection to Hermes.

Tai Fang ‚Äì Director of Capulet Perfumes, obsessed with reuniting Zu with her Capulet past. (Past Life: Tybalt Capulet) Lucrezia de Rosa ‚Äì A scientist working on memory fragrances, desperate to remember her own past life. RITA ‚Äì An advanced AI at Capulet Perfumes.

New York is the primary setting of ZU √ó ORI, blending modernity with echoes of the past. The city serves as a backdrop for discovery, mystery, and supernatural awakenings. Trinity Rose High School ‚Äì A creative arts and tech school where Zu and Ori‚Äôs fates intertwine. Jack‚Äôs Coffee ‚Äì A cozy caf√© where Zu sketches and first locks eyes with Ori. Ori‚Äôs Studio (71 Gansevoort Street) ‚Äì Ori‚Äôs space, where he designs clothing and contemplates the mysterious white dress. The High Line ‚Äì An elevated park near Jack's Coffee where Zu impulsively kisses Ori. Lauren‚Äôs Study ‚Äì Where Lauren and Zu discuss reincarnation, Shakespeare, and Zu's memories of her past. Central Park ‚Äì A key setting where Zu and Ori rekindle their bond. "The Lights" Theater ‚Äì Where Tai and Lucrezia confront Zu, and location of Zu and Ori's performance. The Wright Mansion ‚Äì A historic estate, Hermes' home and site of his hidden holographic lab (The Hall of Memory). Times Square ‚Äì A hub of neon lights where Zu and Ori glimpse their future. Capulet Flagship Store ‚Äì A high-end perfumery in NYC, masking secrets beneath its luxury.

The city of Verona holds timeless imprints of Zu and Ori and plays a vital role in the modern narrative. Palazzo Capuleto ‚Äì Luxurious headquarters for the House of Capulet, located on the Piazza delle Erbe. Piazza delle Erbe ‚Äì Verona‚Äôs historic heart, featured in past-life memories and dreams. Castel San Pietro ‚Äì A historic fortress where Romeo waits in vain for Juliet (before departing for Mantua). Grasshopper Field ‚Äì A sunlit meadow where Romeo and Juliet promised they would always find each other. Capulet Tomb ‚Äì Where Romeo and Juliet took their lives, reimagined by Zu for The Lights.

Before moving to New York, Zu spent her life in Hong Kong, a city rich in culture and contrast. She attended an International School filled with diverse perspectives, grew up in a modern high-rise home, and found inspiration sketching on the Victoria Harbour Ferry, where she first drew Ori‚Äôs face, unknowingly setting herself on the path to rediscovering her past life.

Tabithe‚Äôs Furniture Shop ‚Äì Where a street urchin named Delphine (Hermes' past life) meets, learns from, and stays with Tabithe, a Montague Initiate, on the eve of the French Revolution. Ancient Desert Oasis ‚Äì A past-life memory of Zu‚Äôs, hinting at another life with Ori long before Verona.

Karmic Bonds ‚Äì Zu and Ori‚Äôs souls have intertwined across past lifetimes, leading them to seek each other in the present. Memory Fragments ‚Äì Shards of past life memories surface through dreams, art, d√©j√† vu, and intense emotional connections (time crossings). Recognition Through Eye Contact ‚Äì Zu searches for the boy in her sketches through the eyes of others, knowing she will recognize him when she sees him. This culminates at Jack‚Äôs Coffee, where she and Ori lock eyes‚Äîa silent recognition so intense it stops time, stirring emotions neither can explain.

With a profound link to memory‚Äîa single fragrance can transport someone to a long-forgotten moment, rekindle an emotion, or awaken something buried deep inside. The House of Capulet, with centuries of mastery in perfumery, has refined this relationship between fragrance and memory into an artform. Their lineage traces back to Renaissance Verona, where they first crafted perfumes infused with botanicals and rare extracts to evoke emotions, enhance recall, and stir desire. Over the centuries, their expertise evolved‚Äîblending ancient alchemy with modern neuroscience‚Äîto create scents that do more than evoke memories; they alter them. Capulet perfumes include: Nepenthe (Green) ‚Äì Erases past-life memories, manipulating destiny by controlling who remembers and who forgets. Orpheus (Blue) ‚Äì Induces visions of potential futures, offering glimpses of fate. The Red Perfume (M) ‚Äì Unlocks deep-seated past-life memories, providing direct access to centuries-old experiences (but often at a tragic price).

A phenomenon where past-life events unfold alongside present existence. Triggered by emotional intensity or near-death experiences, allowing characters to relive past events while still conscious in the present. Zu experiences a time crossing after her car accident, recalling her past life as Juliet.

A Montague technique for unlocking past-life memories. Can be guided by another Montague Initiate, like Hermes, or happen involuntarily. Hermes guides Ori through a retrieval session, forcing him to relive his confrontation with Tybalt.

Pre-arranged, destined meetings that shape reincarnated souls' paths. If an appointment is missed, fate shifts, sometimes with catastrophic consequences. Zu and Ori‚Äôs performance at The Lights is a crucial appointment that weaves their fate together.

The Capulet Prophecy states that Juliet (Zu) will return to the Capulets in her next life. If Zu challenges the prophecy, fate will intervene and Romeo (Ori) will die again. Tai, as the reincarnated Tybalt, is obsessed with ensuring Zu's return to the Capulets. Ori, unmoved by the prophecy, follows his intuition and love for Zu, refusing to let fate dictate their future.

A mystical, otherworldly force that manifests in key moments, offering unspoken guidance in times of decision. Represents the presence of un-incarnated Montague Initiates and non-physical beings. A force beyond time, it can bestow visions of past lives to those who experience it. Appears to Zu in her dream of Verona, and during the performance at The Lights.

Led by Tai, this luxury fragrance empire specializes in scents that evoke memory, emotion, and the past. Established over 500 years ago, it has evolved into a modern brand while preserving its historic legacy. Seeks to reclaim Zu (Juliet) to complete its flawed past-life memory fragrance. Their modern logo is a small white dagger, pointing downward.

A secretive organization tracing its roots to the Montagues of Verona. Works to preserve past-life knowledge and uphold the freedom of humanity. Includes Initiates from all time periods and cultures of the world, united by a shared mission. The Montague emblem is a tree within a circle.
A bioscience and AI research foundation connected to Hermes' family. Specializes in futuristic holograms and consciousness research, bridging technology and the mystical elements of memory.

Reincarnation & Past Lives: Memories from past lives resurface, shaping identities in the present. Fate vs. Free Will: Can the cycle of tragedy be broken, or are they doomed to repeat history? Love & Destiny: The unstoppable force of true love across time. Memory & Identity: What happens when you remember‚Äîor forget‚Äîwho you once were? Science & Mysticism: The paths of technology (memory-erasing perfumes) and ancient truth (Montague Initiates).

Zu's Tablet and Drawings üé®üì± ‚Äì A digital canvas for Zu's subconscious Verona memories. The White Dress üëó‚ú® ‚Äì A haunting creation by Ori, an unconscious replica of Juliet's wedding dress. Nepenthe üß™ ‚Äì A memory-erasing perfume, promising peace but hiding the past. The Red Yarn Bracelet üß∂ - Given to Zu by Orion, symbolizing their bond across time. Grasshoppers ü¶óüçÉ ‚Äì A symbol of Juliet and Romeo's time in Verona and Zu's favorite doodle. The Dagger üó°Ô∏èüíî ‚Äì The weapon Juliet used to take her life, and a stage prop at The Lights.
